title: Jesus & Me
desc: Discover who Jesus is through stories, miracles, and His teachings.

lessons.title: Jesus, the Good Shepherd
lessons.excerpt: "I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep." — John 10:11 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus compares himself to a shepherd who truly cares for and protects his sheep—even at great cost.
questions: What does it mean to you that Jesus calls himself your shepherd?
How does a good shepherd act differently from someone who doesn't care about the sheep?
Where in your week could you be a "good shepherd" to a friend?

missions.title: Protect a Friend
missions.desc: This week, stand up for someone who is being left out or picked on. Be their shepherd.

missions.title: Write a Care Note
missions.desc: Write or draw a note for someone who might feel alone. Deliver it in person.

missions.title: Prayer Vigil
missions.desc: Keep a list of 3 people you want to pray for every day this week.

reflectPrompts: How did doing this mission feel?
What was hard about it?
How do you think God felt watching you?

lessons.title: Jesus Calms the Storm
lessons.excerpt: "He awoke, and rebuked the wind, and said to the sea, 'Peace! Be still!' The wind ceased, and there was a great calm." — Mark 4:39 (WEB)
lessons.summary: When a fierce storm scared the disciples, Jesus spoke peace into the chaos—reminding us he has authority over what frightens us.
questions: Have you ever felt like you were in a "storm"—a scary or overwhelming situation?
Why do you think the disciples were afraid even though Jesus was in the boat?
What does it look like to trust Jesus in a stormy moment?

missions.title: Peace Partner
missions.desc: Help calm a tense moment at home. If someone is arguing or upset, be the peacemaker.

missions.title: Storm Journal
missions.desc: Write or draw a "storm" in your life and then write "Peace, be still!" over it.

missions.title: Be the Anchor
missions.desc: Check in on someone who seems stressed or worried. Offer to sit with them.

reflectPrompts: What was your personal storm this week?
How did leaning on faith help (or feel hard)?
What would you do differently next time?

lessons.title: The Prodigal Son
lessons.excerpt: "He arose, and came to his father. But while he was yet far off, his father saw him, and was moved with compassion, and ran, and fell on his neck, and kissed him." — Luke 15:20 (WEB)
lessons.summary: A son wastes his father's money but returns in shame—and the father runs to embrace him. This is how God feels about us.
questions: Why did the father run to his son instead of waiting for an apology?
Is there someone you need to forgive or make up with?
How does it feel to know God welcomes you back no matter what?

missions.title: Make It Right
missions.desc: Apologize to someone you've hurt or drifted from. Mean it.

missions.title: Welcome Table
missions.desc: Invite someone who often eats alone to share your lunch or dinner.

missions.title: Grace Letter
missions.desc: Write a letter to yourself from God's perspective of welcome and love.

reflectPrompts: How did apologizing (or being forgiven) feel?
What did you learn about grace this week?
How has God's welcome changed how you treat others?

lessons.title: The Sermon on the Mount
lessons.excerpt: "Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the Kingdom of Heaven." — Matthew 5:3 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus starts his most famous sermon by turning worldly values upside down—blessing those who feel humble, broken, or overlooked.
questions: Which Beatitude speaks most to you right now and why?
What does it mean to be "poor in spirit"?
How can we build our lives on these blessings instead of what the world values?

missions.title: Humble Servant
missions.desc: Do one household chore or service task without being asked and without telling anyone.

missions.title: Comfort Someone
missions.desc: Find someone who is sad or grieving. Offer your presence and kind words.

missions.title: Peacemaker Day
missions.desc: Go one whole day without speaking negatively about anyone.

reflectPrompts: Which beatitude did you live out this week?
Was it hard? What made it hard?
How did you see God in that moment?

lessons.title: Jesus & the Children
lessons.excerpt: "Suffer the little children to come to me; forbid them not: for of such is the kingdom of God." — Mark 10:14 (KJV)
lessons.summary: When people tried to keep children away from Jesus, he welcomed them and said the Kingdom of Heaven belongs to such as these.
questions: How does it feel knowing Jesus made time especially for children?
What childlike qualities do you think Jesus was pointing to—curiosity, wonder, trust?
How can your family bring that kind of childlike faith to your daily life?

missions.title: Kid Expert
missions.desc: Teach an adult something you know well—a game, a fact, a skill.

missions.title: Wonder Walk
missions.desc: Go outside and find 5 things that make you say "wow." Thank God for each.

missions.title: Welcome Others
missions.desc: At school or church, be the first to welcome someone new or shy.

reflectPrompts: What wonder did you notice this week?
How did your family practice childlike faith together?
What surprised you about God this week?

lessons.title: The Last Supper
lessons.excerpt: "He took bread, and when he had given thanks, he broke it, and gave it to them, saying, 'This is my body which is given for you. Do this in memory of me.'" — Luke 22:19 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus shared one final meal with his disciples, turning a simple dinner into a moment of remembrance, love, and covenant.
questions: Why do you think Jesus chose a meal to remember him by?
What does it mean to do something "in memory of" someone you love?
How can your family meals become more intentional and meaningful?

missions.title: Gratitude Meal
missions.desc: At dinner, have everyone share one thing they're grateful for before eating.

missions.title: Table Talk
missions.desc: Put away all devices at one family meal this week. Just talk.

missions.title: Serve First
missions.desc: At every meal this week, serve someone else's plate before your own.

reflectPrompts: What changed about your meals this week?
How did gratitude change the atmosphere?
What does Jesus' sacrifice mean to you personally?

lessons.title: The Resurrection
lessons.excerpt: "Jesus said to her, 'Woman, why do you weep? Who are you looking for?'" — John 20:15 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Mary Magdalene discovers the empty tomb and encounters the risen Jesus—one of history's most stunning moments of hope defeating despair.
questions: Why do you think Jesus appeared first to Mary, not to important religious leaders?
Easter changes everything—but how does the resurrection matter for Monday mornings?
What "empty tomb" moments—times despair turned to hope—have you experienced?

missions.title: Sunrise Reflection
missions.desc: Wake up early one day this week. Watch the sunrise and think about new beginnings.

missions.title: Share Good News
missions.desc: Tell one person this week something genuinely good and hopeful.

missions.title: Plant Something
missions.desc: Plant a seed (in soil, a cup, or outside) as a symbol of new life.

reflectPrompts: How did resurrection hope show up in your week?
What "new life" are you hoping for right now?
How does knowing Jesus rose change how you face tomorrow?

title: Fruit of the Spirit
desc: Love, joy, peace, patience—learn to grow these character qualities.

lessons.title: Love: The Greatest Fruit
lessons.excerpt: "Love is patient and is kind; love doesn't envy. Love doesn't brag, is not proud." — 1 Corinthians 13:4 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Paul's famous love definition sets the gold standard—it's about actions and choices, not just feelings.
questions: Which part of this love definition is hardest for you?
How is love a "choice" more than just a feeling?
Who in your life needs to experience this kind of love from you this week?

missions.title: Love Letter
missions.desc: Write a genuine thank-you or encouragement note to someone in your family.

missions.title: Patience Test
missions.desc: When you feel impatient today, pause and take 3 deep breaths before reacting.

missions.title: Kind Act
missions.desc: Do one unexpected kind act for a stranger or neighbor.

reflectPrompts: Which part of 1 Cor 13 did you live out?
What made it hard?
What did love look like in action this week?

lessons.title: Joy: More Than Happiness
lessons.excerpt: "The joy of Yahweh is your strength." — Nehemiah 8:10 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Joy in scripture isn't about circumstances—it's a deep-rooted strength that comes from knowing God is with you.
questions: What's the difference between joy and just feeling happy?
When has your family had joy even in a hard time?
What practices or habits help you stay joyful?

missions.title: Laugh Together
missions.desc: Watch a funny video or tell jokes as a family for 15 minutes tonight.

missions.title: Joy List
missions.desc: Each day, write 3 things that gave you joy. Share one at dinner.

missions.title: Joy Prayer
missions.desc: Pray specifically for someone who has lost their joy.

reflectPrompts: What gave you the most joy this week?
How is joy different from what you expected?
How did you pass joy on to someone else?

lessons.title: Peace: More Than Quiet
lessons.excerpt: "The peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus." — Philippians 4:7 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Paul wrote this from prison—showing that peace is not about easy circumstances but a supernatural guard for your heart.
questions: How can someone have peace in a hard situation?
What steals your peace most often?
What would change if you truly believed God was guarding your heart?

missions.title: Peace Zone
missions.desc: Create a quiet corner in your room. Spend 5 mins there in silence each day.

missions.title: Peace Keeper
missions.desc: When conflict arises in your home, be the first to work toward peace.

missions.title: Memorize Philippians 4:7
missions.desc: Memorize this verse this week and share it with someone who needs it.

reflectPrompts: Where did you find unexpected peace?
What still steals your peace?
How are you growing in trusting God's peace?

lessons.title: Patience: The Long Game
lessons.excerpt: "Tribulation produces perseverance; and perseverance, proven character; and proven character, hope." — Romans 5:3–4 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Paul explains that patience isn't passive waiting—it's active trust that builds strength of character over time.
questions: What is something you're waiting for right now?
How do you think waiting builds character?
Can you think of a time when being patient paid off?

missions.title: No Rush Day
missions.desc: For one whole day, practice not rushing. Move slower and notice more.

missions.title: Long-Term Project
missions.desc: Start something that won't finish for weeks (garden, puzzle, craft, skill).

missions.title: Wait for Others
missions.desc: Deliberately let others go first in lines, decisions, or conversations.

reflectPrompts: Where did you practice patience this week?
What was the hardest moment?
How did patience change the outcome?

lessons.title: Kindness: Every Day Acts
lessons.excerpt: "Be kind to one another, tenderhearted, forgiving each other, just as God also in Christ forgave you." — Ephesians 4:32 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Kindness is linked directly to forgiveness—we give it because we've received it. It's a response to grace, not just etiquette.
questions: Is it easier to be kind to strangers or to people you know well? Why?
How does knowing God forgave you change how you forgive others?
Who in your world needs an unexpected act of kindness this week?

missions.title: Kindness Cards
missions.desc: Make 3 cards with kind messages and leave them somewhere they'll be found.

missions.title: Service Day
missions.desc: Clean up a space—a park, a neighbor's yard, the church parking lot.

missions.title: Warm Welcome
missions.desc: Greet every person you pass today with eye contact and a smile.

reflectPrompts: How did random kindness change your day?
Was it easy or awkward? Why?
What would happen if you did this every week?

lessons.title: Goodness: Character Inside Out
lessons.excerpt: "Surely goodness and loving kindness shall follow me all the days of my life." — Psalm 23:6 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Goodness isn't just doing good things—it's developing a good character from the inside, so right actions flow naturally.
questions: What's the difference between acting good and being good?
What habits are building goodness in you right now?
How does God's goodness inspire your own?

missions.title: Character Check
missions.desc: Ask a trusted friend: "What's one way I could grow in goodness?" Listen without defending.

missions.title: Goodness Biography
missions.desc: Read about a person of great character. Share one thing that inspired you.

missions.title: Integrity Test
missions.desc: Do the right thing in one situation this week when no one is watching.

reflectPrompts: What did you learn about goodness this week?
Where did your character show up clearly?
How are you becoming more good from the inside?

lessons.title: Self-Control: The Master Key
lessons.excerpt: "Like a city that is broken down and without walls is a man whose spirit is without restraint." — Proverbs 25:28 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Ancient cities relied on strong walls—the Bible says self-control is your inner wall, protecting everything good inside you.
questions: What "walls" do you need in your own life—habits or limits that protect you?
What area is hardest for you to control: words, screen time, food, anger?
How does self-control actually make you more free, not less?

missions.title: Screen Sabbath
missions.desc: Take one day off from screens (except school needs). Fill the time with something real.

missions.title: Discipline Streak
missions.desc: Do one healthy habit every day for 7 days: walk, pray, read, journal.

missions.title: Filter Challenge
missions.desc: Before speaking when upset, ask: "Is this True, Helpful, Kind?" This week, pause 3 times.

reflectPrompts: What habit of self-control did you practice?
What surprised you about it?
How is self-control making you stronger?

title: Courage & Anxiety
desc: Biblical tools for facing fears and worry with faith.

lessons.title: Don't Be Afraid
lessons.excerpt: "Don't be afraid, for I am with you. Don't be dismayed, for I am your God." — Isaiah 41:10 (WEB)
lessons.summary: God spoke this to Israel in exile—not a promise of no problems, but a promise of His constant presence.
questions: What are you currently afraid of?
How does knowing God is present change how you face fear?
What would you do differently this week if you truly believed God was with you?

missions.title: Brave Act
missions.desc: Do one thing this week that scares you a little. Then reflect on it.

missions.title: Tell Your Fear
missions.desc: Share one fear with a trusted family member. Ask them to pray for you.

missions.title: Memorize It
missions.desc: Memorize Isaiah 41:10 and say it out loud when fear comes.

reflectPrompts: What did you face with courage?
Was God's presence real to you in that moment?
How has your fear changed?

lessons.title: When You Feel Anxious
lessons.excerpt: "In nothing be anxious, but in everything, by prayer and petition with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God." — Philippians 4:6 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Paul's remedy for anxiety is startlingly simple: replace worry with prayer and gratitude. Research now confirms this practice reduces anxiety.
questions: What do you worry about most? Does worrying change it?
How is prayer different from just "positive thinking"?
What can you be genuinely grateful for even when things are hard?

missions.title: Anxiety Journal
missions.desc: Write down your worries, then cross them out and write a prayer over each one.

missions.title: Gratitude Swap
missions.desc: Each time you catch yourself worrying, name 3 things you're grateful for instead.

missions.title: Pray Together
missions.desc: Share one worry with your family and pray over it together tonight.

reflectPrompts: How did replacing worry with prayer feel?
Was it hard? What helped?
How has your anxiety changed this week?

lessons.title: David & Goliath
lessons.excerpt: "David said to the Philistine, 'You come to me with a sword, with a spear, and with a javelin, but I come to you in the name of Yahweh of Armies.'" — 1 Samuel 17:45 (WEB)
lessons.summary: A teenage shepherd defeated a giant warrior—not because he was strongest, but because he trusted God's power over his own.
questions: What is your "Goliath"—the big, scary challenge you're facing right now?
David ran toward the giant. What would running toward your fear look like?
How does bringing God into a scary situation change it?

missions.title: Face Your Giant
missions.desc: Identify one "Goliath" situation. Take one small brave step toward it this week.

missions.title: 5 Smooth Stones
missions.desc: Write 5 strengths or gifts God has given you. Remember them when afraid.

missions.title: Courage Cheer
missions.desc: Encourage someone who is facing their own giant. Send a message or tell them in person.

reflectPrompts: What giant did you face?
How did God show up?
What would you say to someone facing the same giant?

lessons.title: Elijah's Burnout
lessons.excerpt: "An angel touched him, and said to him, 'Arise and eat.'" — 1 Kings 19:5 (WEB)
lessons.summary: After a great victory, Elijah collapsed in exhaustion and despair. God's first response was sleep and food—rest is part of courage.
questions: Have you ever felt completely burnt out or exhausted?
Why do you think God focused on Elijah's physical needs first?
What does it tell us about God that he cares about our rest?

missions.title: Rest Practice
missions.desc: Go to bed 30 minutes earlier every night this week.

missions.title: Nourish Well
missions.desc: Pay attention to what you eat this week. Choose one nourishing habit to add.

missions.title: Still Walk
missions.desc: Take a 15-minute walk in nature with no phone. Just breathe and notice.

reflectPrompts: How did intentional rest change your energy?
Where did you feel God's care this week?
What burnout habits do you want to change?

lessons.title: Joshua's Commission
lessons.excerpt: "Be strong and courageous. Don't be afraid, and don't be dismayed, for Yahweh your God is with you wherever you go." — Joshua 1:9 (WEB)
lessons.summary: God spoke this before Joshua faced the impossible task of leading a nation. Courage was commanded—not just hoped for.
questions: If courage is a command, what does that tell us about how to develop it?
What task feels impossible to you right now?
How can your family build courage in each other?

missions.title: New Territory
missions.desc: Try something completely new this week—a new skill, food, conversation, or place.

missions.title: Lead Something
missions.desc: Take initiative to organize or lead a family activity this week.

missions.title: Speak Up
missions.desc: Say something true but difficult this week. Speak up when you see something wrong.

reflectPrompts: What new territory did you enter?
How did leading feel?
Where did you speak courage this week?

lessons.title: Peace Like a River
lessons.excerpt: "Oh that you had listened to my commandments! Then your peace would have been like a river." — Isaiah 48:18 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Isaiah paints peace as a flowing river—constant, natural, and life-giving when we're connected to God's way of living.
questions: What does "peace like a river" look like in real life?
What disrupts the flow of peace in your life most often?
What one choice could you make this week to flow more toward peace?

missions.title: Peace Practice
missions.desc: Spend 10 minutes each morning in quiet before screens. Do this 5 of 7 days.

missions.title: Be the Peace
missions.desc: In one tense situation this week, choose peace instead of escalation.

missions.title: Worship Therapy
missions.desc: When anxiety rises, play worship music for 5 minutes and sing along.

reflectPrompts: When did peace flow most naturally?
What blocked the river this week?
How is your relationship with peace growing?

lessons.title: The Armor of God
lessons.excerpt: "Put on the whole armor of God, that you may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil." — Ephesians 6:11 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Paul describes six pieces of spiritual armor—each representing a dimension of our inner life that needs to be protected and strengthened.
questions: Which piece of armor do you think you most need right now?
How is prayer described as a weapon, not just a spiritual discipline?
What would "putting on the armor" look like practically every morning?

missions.title: Morning Armor
missions.desc: Each morning this week, say: "I put on truth, righteousness, peace, faith, salvation, and God's Word."

missions.title: Scripture Sword
missions.desc: Memorize one verse this week and use it when temptation or fear comes.

missions.title: Intercessor
missions.desc: Pray for three people in spiritual battles: someone sick, someone doubting, someone straying.

reflectPrompts: Which piece of armor did you use?
How did having a "prepared mind" change your day?
What spiritual battle did God help you win?

title: Words & Actions
desc: Honesty, kindness in speech, and how words shape the world.

lessons.title: The Power of the Tongue
lessons.excerpt: "Death and life are in the power of the tongue; and those who love it will eat its fruit." — Proverbs 18:21 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Solomon recognized what neuroscience now confirms: words have enormous power to build up or tear down.
questions: Think of a time someone's words greatly impacted you—positively or negatively.
Why do you think the Bible compares the tongue to life and death?
What one change to your speech would make the biggest difference this week?

missions.title: Word Fast
missions.desc: Go one day without speaking negatively, complaining, or gossiping.

missions.title: Life Words
missions.desc: Intentionally speak words of life to 3 different people today.

missions.title: Speech Audit
missions.desc: At the end of each day this week, reflect: did my words give life or bring harm today?

reflectPrompts: When did your words give life this week?
When did you struggle to control your tongue?
What changed when you spoke more intentionally?

lessons.title: Honesty Over Everything
lessons.excerpt: "Lying lips are an abomination to Yahweh, but those who act faithfully are his delight." — Proverbs 12:22 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Honesty is not just a rule—it's fundamental to God's character and to trust in all relationships.
questions: Why is honesty so important in a family?
Is it ever right to tell a "kind lie"? How do you navigate that?
What makes it hard to be fully honest sometimes?

missions.title: Truth Day
missions.desc: For one whole day, commit to saying only what is completely true. Notice what changes.

missions.title: Honesty Conversation
missions.desc: Have a genuinely honest conversation with a family member about something important.

missions.title: Kindly Correct
missions.desc: Gently and kindly correct a misunderstanding you've let slide for too long.

reflectPrompts: How did choosing honesty feel?
What was hard about it?
How did honesty affect your relationships this week?

lessons.title: Gossip & What It Costs
lessons.excerpt: "For lack of wood, a fire goes out. Without a gossip, a quarrel dies down." — Proverbs 26:20 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Gossip is the fuel of conflict—remove it and many fights simply die. Solomon's wisdom is practical and protective.
questions: Why do you think gossip is tempting even when we know it's harmful?
Have you ever been the subject of gossip? How did it feel?
What is one practical rule you could set for your family or friend group about gossip?

missions.title: Secret Keeper
missions.desc: This week, if someone tells you private information, keep it completely private.

missions.title: Fire Extinguisher
missions.desc: When gossip starts in a group, gently change the subject or say something positive about the person.

missions.title: Speak Well
missions.desc: Whenever you mention someone who isn't present, only say things you'd say to their face.

reflectPrompts: Where did you fight the gossip temptation?
How did keeping confidences feel?
What did you notice about conversation dynamics?

lessons.title: Words That Heal
lessons.excerpt: "Pleasant words are like a honeycomb: sweet to the soul, and health to the bones." — Proverbs 16:24 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Kind, well-chosen words are literally compared to medicine—they have the power to heal and restore.
questions: Who in your life needs healing words right now?
What stops you from saying encouraging things when you feel them?
How can your family make encouragement a daily practice?

missions.title: Honey Words
missions.desc: Tell someone something genuinely encouraging that you've been holding back.

missions.title: Healing Note
missions.desc: Write a note to someone who is hurting. Focus only on encouragement and love.

missions.title: Daily Compliment
missions.desc: Give one genuine compliment per day for 7 days to different people.

reflectPrompts: How did speaking healing words feel?
Who responded most meaningfully?
How are you growing in encouragement?

lessons.title: The Way You Ask Matters
lessons.excerpt: "A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger." — Proverbs 15:1 (WEB)
lessons.summary: How we say something often matters more than what we say. A gentle tone can de-escalate any conflict.
questions: Think of a recent disagreement. How did your tone affect the outcome?
What techniques help you respond gently when you're upset?
How can your family practice this together?

missions.title: Tone Challenge
missions.desc: In one difficult conversation this week, lower your voice and soften your tone intentionally.

missions.title: Restate & Listen
missions.desc: Before responding in an argument, restate what the other person said first.

missions.title: Calm Text
missions.desc: Before sending any upset text or message, wait 10 minutes and reread it.

reflectPrompts: When did your tone help or hurt this week?
What was the hardest moment to respond gently?
How is your communication style growing?

lessons.title: Actions Speak Louder
lessons.excerpt: "My little children, let's not love in word only, or with the tongue only, but in deed and truth." — 1 John 3:18 (WEB)
lessons.summary: John cuts through verbal niceness—real love shows up in what we do, not just what we say.
questions: Think of someone whose love you feel through their actions. What do they do?
Where might you be saying loving things but not backing them up?
What is one concrete action you can take this week to show love?

missions.title: Fix Something
missions.desc: Do a practical act of service that someone close to you needs.

missions.title: Show Up
missions.desc: Be physically present for someone who needs support—visit, sit with, be there.

missions.title: Action Gift
missions.desc: Give your time instead of a thing. Offer 30 minutes of undivided attention.

reflectPrompts: What action did you take to show love?
How was it received?
How does doing feel different from saying?

lessons.title: Speaking Truth in Love
lessons.excerpt: "But speaking truth in love, we may grow up in all things into him, who is the head, Christ." — Ephesians 4:15 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Truth without love is brutal. Love without truth is hollow. The Bible calls us to hold them together.
questions: When is it loving to tell someone a hard truth?
How do you tell when "honesty" is actually just unkindness with an excuse?
What is a truth you need to share with someone in love this week?

missions.title: Loving Truth
missions.desc: Share something true but kind with someone who needs to hear it. Do it with gentleness.

missions.title: Loving Listen
missions.desc: Ask someone: "Can I tell you one honest thing I've noticed about you?"—and listen to their reaction.

missions.title: Self Check
missions.desc: Ask: "Am I speaking truth with love, or am I just speaking?"—check your last 5 conversations.

reflectPrompts: How did speaking truth in love go?
What made it hard?
How are truth and love growing together in you?

title: Prayer & Gratitude
desc: Learn to talk with God—how to pray and why gratitude changes everything.

lessons.title: How to Pray
lessons.excerpt: "Pray like this: 'Our Father in heaven, may your name be kept holy. Let your Kingdom come.'" — Matthew 6:9 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus gave his followers a simple prayer template—not a spell to recite, but a structure that covers everything we need.
questions: What do you notice about how Jesus starts prayer—"Our Father"?
What does it mean to pray for God's Kingdom to come?
How can the Lord's Prayer shape your own prayer life?

missions.title: Lord's Prayer Week
missions.desc: Pray the Lord's Prayer every morning this week. Notice something new each day.

missions.title: Personal Prayer
missions.desc: Write your own prayer based on the Lord's Prayer structure.

missions.title: Pray Together
missions.desc: Lead your family in prayer one evening this week.

reflectPrompts: What did you notice new in the Lord's Prayer?
How did your own prayer grow?
What was hardest about leading prayer?

lessons.title: God Hears You
lessons.excerpt: "The righteous cry, and Yahweh hears, and delivers them out of all their troubles." — Psalm 34:17 (WEB)
lessons.summary: David wrote this from personal experience of deliverance. Prayer is not shouting into void—it connects to a God who listens.
questions: Have you ever felt like your prayers weren't heard? What was that like?
Why do you think God sometimes seems silent even when we pray?
What would change if you truly believed God heard every prayer you prayed?

missions.title: Prayer Log
missions.desc: Keep a simple log of prayers and answers this week. Even small ones count.

missions.title: Persistent Prayer
missions.desc: Pick one prayer you've given up on. Bring it back to God this week.

missions.title: Pray Out Loud
missions.desc: Pray out loud once this week—alone or with family. Notice how it feels different.

reflectPrompts: What did you notice God doing this week?
Did you see any prayer answers?
How has your confidence in prayer changed?

lessons.title: Gratitude Changes Your Brain
lessons.excerpt: "In everything give thanks, for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus toward you." — 1 Thessalonians 5:18 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Science and scripture agree: gratitude rewires us toward joy. Paul's "give thanks in everything" is not naivety—it's a practiced discipline.
questions: Is it possible to be grateful even in a hard situation? How?
What is something you often take for granted?
How could your family build a daily gratitude habit?

missions.title: Gratitude Journal
missions.desc: Write 3 specific things you're grateful for every day this week.

missions.title: Gratitude Call
missions.desc: Call or text someone specifically to thank them for something.

missions.title: Grateful Meals
missions.desc: Start every dinner with two minutes of sharing what you're grateful for.

reflectPrompts: What surprised you in your gratitude list?
How did gratitude change your mood or perspective?
What will you keep doing after this lesson?

lessons.title: Praying for Others
lessons.excerpt: "Confess your offenses to one another, and pray for one another, that you may be healed." — James 5:16 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Intercession—praying for others—is one of the most powerful things Christians do for each other and for the world.
questions: Who do you regularly pray for? Who should you add to that list?
Why might praying for someone change your feelings toward them?
How can your family become a praying family for your community?

missions.title: Prayer List
missions.desc: Make a prayer list of 7 people (one per day). Pray for each one specifically.

missions.title: Tell Someone
missions.desc: Tell one person you've been praying for them. Watch their reaction.

missions.title: Neighborhood Prayer
missions.desc: Walk around your neighborhood or school and pray silently for the people who live/work there.

reflectPrompts: How did praying for others change YOU?
Did anyone respond to knowing you prayed?
How has your circle of concern grown?

lessons.title: Fasting & Focus
lessons.excerpt: "But when you fast, anoint your head, and wash your face; so that you are not seen by men to be fasting." — Matthew 6:17–18 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus assumed his followers would fast—not if, but when. A disciplined practice of going without something to focus on God.
questions: What is fasting, and why would going without something help you focus on God?
What could you "fast" from this week that isn't food? (screens, negativity, social media)
How does denying ourselves small things build larger spiritual strength?

missions.title: Tech Fast
missions.desc: Fast from one digital thing (social media, games, TV) for one full day.

missions.title: Meal Fast
missions.desc: Skip one meal this week. Use that time to pray instead of eat.

missions.title: Quiet Fast
missions.desc: Take 30 minutes of complete silence. No music, no talking, no screens. Just pray.

reflectPrompts: What did fasting teach you?
What was hardest to go without?
How did the focus time with God feel?

lessons.title: When Prayer Feels Hard
lessons.excerpt: "The Spirit also helps our weaknesses, for we don't know how to pray as we ought. But the Spirit himself makes intercession for us with groanings which can't be uttered." — Romans 8:26 (WEB)
lessons.summary: When you don't know how to pray—when words fail—the Holy Spirit prays through you. You never pray alone.
questions: Have you had seasons when prayer felt empty or hard? What caused it?
What does it mean that the Spirit prays when we can't find words?
What helps you reconnect with prayer when you've drifted?

missions.title: Musical Prayer
missions.desc: Listen to a worship song and let it be your prayer. Then sit in silence for 3 minutes.

missions.title: Nature Prayer
missions.desc: Go outside and pray out loud to creation—notice what you feel.

missions.title: Prayer Letter
missions.desc: Write a letter to God about everything you're feeling right now—no filters.

reflectPrompts: What helped your prayer feel more real this week?
Did the Spirit meet you in your weakness?
How is your prayer life different than a week ago?

lessons.title: A Life of Prayer
lessons.excerpt: "Pray without ceasing." — 1 Thessalonians 5:17 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Paul's shortest command is one of his biggest invitations—to make prayer not a task but a way of being.
questions: What would "praying without ceasing" look like in a normal school or work day?
How can your family weave prayer into ordinary moments?
What one habit would most help you become a person of prayer?

missions.title: Prayer Alarm
missions.desc: Set 3 alarms per day this week. Each time one goes off, pause for a 30-second prayer.

missions.title: Car Prayers
missions.desc: Turn every car ride this week into prayer time as a family.

missions.title: Bookend Prayers
missions.desc: Pray first thing after waking and last thing before sleep for one full week.

reflectPrompts: How many prayers did you pray this week?
What changed about your ordinary moments?
How is prayer becoming part of who you are?

title: Creation & Science
desc: Explore how God's creation reveals His power, wisdom, and love for discovery.

lessons.title: In the Beginning
lessons.excerpt: "In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth. The earth was formless and empty. Darkness was on the surface of the deep and God's Spirit was hovering over the surface of the waters. God said, 'Let there be light,' and there was light." — Genesis 1:1-3 (WEB)
lessons.summary: The Bible opens with the most incredible moment ever — God creating everything from nothing! Day by day, God shaped light, sky, land, seas, plants, stars, animals, and more. Each time He looked at what He made, He called it good. This story shows us that God is amazingly powerful and creative, and that everything in our world started with His love and imagination.
questions: What is your favorite part of creation — the ocean, the stars, animals, or something else? Why does it amaze you?
What does it mean that God called His creation 'good'? What does that tell us about how God sees the world?
How can remembering that God made everything change the way you treat the world around you today?

missions.title: Creation Countdown
missions.desc: Read Genesis 1 and draw or list something God made on each of the six days of creation.

missions.title: Creation Photo Walk
missions.desc: Go on a walk outside and take photos (or draw pictures) of seven things in nature that remind you of God's creativity.

missions.title: Creation Journal
missions.desc: Keep a journal for one week. Each day, write about one amazing thing in creation you noticed and thank God for it.

reflectPrompts: What was the most surprising or beautiful thing you noticed in creation during your mission?
How did paying attention to the world around you make you feel about God?
Where do you see God's creativity and care when you look at nature?

lessons.title: Made in God's Image
lessons.excerpt: "God created man in his own image. In God's image he created him; male and female he created them." — Genesis 1:27 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Out of everything God made, people are extra special — we are created in God's own image! That doesn't mean we look exactly like God, but it means we can think, love, create, and choose — just like He does. Every single person is valuable and worthy of love because God made each of us to reflect who He is.
questions: What does it mean to you that you are made in God's image? How does that make you feel about yourself?
If every person is made in God's image, how should we treat people who are different from us?
What is one special ability or talent you have that you think reflects God's creativity in you?

missions.title: Mirror Moment
missions.desc: Look in a mirror and say, 'I am made in God's image and I am loved.' Then tell one other person that they are made in God's image too.

missions.title: Image Bearer Art
missions.desc: Create a piece of art — a drawing, poem, song, or craft — that celebrates what makes you unique as someone made in God's image.

missions.title: Encouragement Campaign
missions.desc: Write encouraging notes to five different people this week reminding them they are special and made in God's image.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to tell yourself or someone else that they are made in God's image?
Did doing this mission change how you see yourself or other people?
How do you think God feels when He sees you using your unique gifts and talents?

lessons.title: The Heavens Declare His Glory
lessons.excerpt: "The heavens declare the glory of God. The expanse shows his handiwork. Day after day they pour out speech, and night after night they display knowledge." — Psalm 19:1-2 (WEB)
lessons.summary: King David looked up at the sky and was blown away — the stars, the sun, and the endless universe were all shouting about how great God is! Even without words, creation speaks to us every single day about God's power and beauty. When we study the natural world — from tiny cells to massive galaxies — we are discovering the amazing things God has made.
questions: Have you ever looked at the night sky or a sunset and felt amazed? What was that moment like?
How can studying science — like learning about stars, weather, or animals — actually help us learn more about God?
If creation 'declares' God's glory without words, what is it saying to you today?

missions.title: Stargazer
missions.desc: Go outside at night (with a parent) and spend at least five minutes looking at the stars. Talk about what you see and how it makes you feel about God.

missions.title: Science & Wonder Report
missions.desc: Research one amazing science fact (like how far away stars are, how a butterfly transforms, or how our hearts beat). Write a short report connecting it to God's creativity.

missions.title: Glory Journal
missions.desc: For five days, observe something in nature each day (sunrise, clouds, plants, animals, weather). Write or draw what you see and include a prayer of praise to God.

reflectPrompts: What was the most awe-inspiring thing you observed or learned during your mission?
How did slowing down to look at creation change your day or your mood?
Do you feel closer to God when you explore the world He made? Why or why not?

lessons.title: Caretakers of the Earth
lessons.excerpt: "Yahweh God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden to cultivate and keep it." — Genesis 2:15 (WEB)
lessons.summary: God didn't just make the earth and walk away — He asked people to take care of it! God placed the first humans in a beautiful garden and gave them the job of looking after it. This means caring for animals, plants, water, and land is actually something God wants us to do. Being a good steward of the earth is one way we honor God.
questions: What does it mean to be a 'steward' or caretaker of something? Have you ever been responsible for taking care of something important?
Why do you think God chose to give humans the job of caring for the earth instead of just doing it Himself?
What is one thing your family could do differently to take better care of God's creation?

missions.title: Plant a Seed
missions.desc: Plant a seed or small plant and commit to watering it and caring for it. Watch it grow as a reminder of your role as a caretaker.

missions.title: Creation Cleanup
missions.desc: Organize a cleanup of your yard, a park, or a neighborhood area. Pick up trash and leave the area better than you found it.

missions.title: Stewardship Challenge
missions.desc: For one full week, find a new way each day to care for creation: recycle, save water, feed birds, reduce waste, pick up litter, care for a pet, or plant something.

reflectPrompts: What did it feel like to actively take care of something in God's creation?
Did your mission change the way you think about your responsibility toward the earth?
How do you think God feels when He sees us caring for the world He made?

lessons.title: The Rainbow Promise
lessons.excerpt: "I set my rainbow in the cloud, and it will be a sign of a covenant between me and the earth. When I bring a cloud over the earth, that the rainbow will be seen in the cloud, I will remember my covenant, which is between me and you and every living creature of all flesh, and the waters will no more become a flood to destroy all flesh." — Genesis 9:13-15 (WEB)
lessons.summary: After a great flood covered the earth, Noah and his family finally stepped onto dry land. God made a very special promise — a covenant — and placed a rainbow in the sky as a sign that He would never flood the whole earth again. This story teaches us that even after difficult times, God is faithful. He keeps His promises, and He gives us signs of hope when we need them most.
questions: How do you think Noah felt when he saw the rainbow for the very first time? Have you ever felt relief after a hard time?
What does it mean that God makes 'covenants' or promises? Why is it important that God keeps His promises?
When you see a rainbow, what will you remember about God's faithfulness?

missions.title: Rainbow Reminder
missions.desc: Draw or paint a rainbow and write God's promise from Genesis 9:13 on it. Hang it somewhere you'll see it every day.

missions.title: Promise Collector
missions.desc: Find and write down three promises God makes in the Bible (ask a parent or search online for help). Share them with your family and talk about what they mean.

missions.title: Faithfulness Week
missions.desc: Make a personal promise to someone (a parent, sibling, or friend) and keep it faithfully for an entire week. At the end, journal about what you learned about faithfulness.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to focus on God's promises this week?
Was it easy or hard to keep your own promises? What did that teach you about faithfulness?
How does knowing that God always keeps His promises make you feel during tough times?

lessons.title: The Gift of Wisdom
lessons.excerpt: "For Yahweh gives wisdom. Out of his mouth comes knowledge and understanding. He lays up sound wisdom for the upright. He is a shield to those who walk in integrity." — Proverbs 2:6-7 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Did you know that God actually wants us to be curious and learn new things? The book of Proverbs tells us that all true wisdom and knowledge come from God. When we study, explore, and ask questions, we are using the amazing brain God gave us! Seeking wisdom isn't just about school — it's about learning how to live well, make good choices, and understand God's incredible world.
questions: What is the difference between being smart and being wise? Can you think of an example?
Why do you think God wants us to seek wisdom and knowledge? How does learning help us grow closer to Him?
What is one question about the world or about God that you would love to find the answer to?

missions.title: Wisdom Verse
missions.desc: Memorize Proverbs 2:6 and say it out loud to a family member. Talk about what it means together.

missions.title: Curious Learner
missions.desc: Pick a topic you're curious about (space, animals, the ocean, history) and spend 30 minutes learning about it. Then share one cool fact and how it shows God's wisdom.

missions.title: Wisdom Interviews
missions.desc: Interview three adults you respect and ask them: 'What is the wisest thing you've ever learned?' Write down their answers and share what you learned with your family.

reflectPrompts: What new thing did you learn during your mission? How did it make you feel?
Do you think learning and growing in knowledge helps you understand God better? How?
How can you keep seeking wisdom in your everyday life, not just at school?

lessons.title: Faith and Big Questions
lessons.excerpt: "By faith we understand that the universe has been framed by the word of God, so that what is seen has not been made out of things which are visible." — Hebrews 11:3 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Sometimes people think faith and curiosity are opposites — but they're actually great partners! Faith helps us trust God even when we can't see everything, and curiosity drives us to explore and discover more of His amazing creation. It's okay to ask big questions like 'How did God make the universe?' or 'Why did God create me?' Asking questions doesn't weaken our faith — it helps it grow stronger and deeper.
questions: What is the biggest question you've ever had about God or about the world? Did you find an answer?
Why do you think some people believe that faith and science don't go together? Do you agree or disagree?
How can asking hard questions actually help your faith grow stronger instead of weaker?

missions.title: Big Question Box
missions.desc: Write down three big questions you have about God, faith, or the universe. Share them with a parent or mentor and talk about them together.

missions.title: Faith & Discovery Report
missions.desc: Research a famous scientist who was also a person of faith (like Isaac Newton, George Washington Carver, or Mary Anning). Write a short report about how they saw faith and science working together.

missions.title: Wonder Discussion
missions.desc: Lead a family discussion night about faith and curiosity. Prepare three big questions, look up Bible verses that relate to each, and guide the conversation. Write down what everyone shared.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to explore big questions openly? Did anything surprise you?
Do you feel more comfortable asking tough questions about faith now? Why or why not?
How do you think God feels when we bring our biggest, hardest questions to Him?

title: Friendship
desc: Learn what it means to be a true friend through Bible stories and real-life practice.

lessons.title: A Friendship Like No Other
lessons.excerpt: "The soul of Jonathan was knit with the soul of David, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul." — 1 Samuel 18:1 (WEB)
lessons.summary: When David defeated Goliath, he met Jonathan — the king's son. Jonathan saw David's bravery and faith, and they became the closest of friends. Jonathan even gave David his own robe and armor as a sign of loyalty. Their friendship shows us that true friends love each other deeply and stand by one another no matter what — even when it costs them something.
questions: Who is someone you feel really close to, and what makes that friendship special?
Jonathan gave David his robe and weapons — what do you think that meant to David?
How can you show a friend that you care about them as much as you care about yourself?

missions.title: Friendship Note
missions.desc: Write a short note or draw a picture telling a friend why they are special to you and give it to them.

missions.title: Generous Gift
missions.desc: Give something meaningful to a friend — like a favorite book, toy, or handmade gift — as a sign of your friendship.

missions.title: Loyalty Challenge
missions.desc: For one full week, find a way to encourage or stand up for a friend every single day, even when it's not easy.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to do something special for your friend?
Did showing loyalty or generosity change how you feel about your friendship?
How do you think God feels when He sees friends loving each other well?

lessons.title: Standing By Your Side
lessons.excerpt: "Don't urge me to leave you, and to return from following you, for where you go, I will go; and where you stay, I will stay. Your people will be my people, and your God, my God." — Ruth 1:16 (WEB)
lessons.summary: After losing their husbands, Naomi told her daughters-in-law to go back to their own families. But Ruth refused to leave. She chose to stay with Naomi through sadness, hunger, and an uncertain future. Ruth's loyalty shows us that real friendship means being there for someone even when life gets really hard — not just when things are fun and easy.
questions: Have you ever had a friend go through a hard time? What did you do?
Why do you think Ruth chose to stay with Naomi instead of going back to her own home?
What's one thing you can do this week to support a friend who might be struggling?

missions.title: Check-In Call
missions.desc: Reach out to a friend you haven't talked to in a while — call, text, or visit and ask how they're really doing.

missions.title: Comfort Delivery
missions.desc: Make or buy a small treat and deliver it to a friend or neighbor who is going through a tough time.

missions.title: Faithful Friend
missions.desc: Commit to checking in on someone who is going through a hard season at least three times over the next two weeks.

reflectPrompts: How did your friend react when you reached out to them?
What feelings came up for you when you showed up for someone in a hard moment?
How does God show you that He stays by your side, even in tough times?

lessons.title: Choosing Friends Wisely
lessons.excerpt: "He appointed twelve, that they might be with him, and that he might send them out to preach." — Mark 3:14 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus didn't pick His closest friends by accident. He prayed all night and then chose twelve disciples to walk closely with Him. Some were fishermen, one was a tax collector — they were very different — but Jesus chose people He could invest in and grow alongside. This teaches us that choosing good friends is important, and that the best friendships help us become who God wants us to be.
questions: What qualities do you look for when choosing your closest friends?
Jesus chose people who were very different from each other — why do you think that was a good idea?
How can your friendships help you grow closer to God?

missions.title: Friendship Qualities List
missions.desc: Write down five qualities you think make a great friend, then think about whether you show those qualities too.

missions.title: Growth Buddy
missions.desc: Ask a friend to learn something new together — read a Bible chapter, start a project, or practice a skill side by side.

missions.title: Prayerful Choices
missions.desc: Spend time each day this week praying for your friendships — ask God to help you be a good friend and to bring good friends into your life.

reflectPrompts: What did you learn about the kind of friend you want to be?
Did doing something with a friend help you grow? How?
How do you think God guides you in choosing the right friends?

lessons.title: A Friend to Everyone
lessons.excerpt: "But a certain Samaritan, as he traveled, came where he was. When he saw him, he was moved with compassion, came to him, and bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine." — Luke 10:33-34 (WEB)
lessons.summary: In Jesus' famous parable, a man was beaten and left on the road. A priest and a Levite both walked right past him, but a Samaritan — someone most people looked down on — stopped and cared for the hurting man. Jesus used this story to teach that being a true friend isn't about labels or popularity — it's about showing kindness and compassion to whoever needs it, even strangers.
questions: Have you ever noticed someone being left out or hurting? What did you do?
Why do you think the priest and Levite walked past the injured man?
How can you be like the Good Samaritan at school, in your neighborhood, or online?

missions.title: Kindness Moment
missions.desc: Do one unexpected act of kindness for someone you don't know very well — hold a door, share a snack, or offer a compliment.

missions.title: Empty Chair Invitation
missions.desc: At lunch, recess, or a group activity, invite someone who is sitting alone to join you and your friends.

missions.title: Compassion Project
missions.desc: Organize a small service project with friends — make care kits for a shelter, write encouraging cards, or volunteer together.

reflectPrompts: How did it feel to reach out to someone you didn't know well?
Did you notice anything change in that person — or in yourself — after you showed kindness?
How do you think God sees us when we show compassion to strangers?

lessons.title: Iron Sharpens Iron
lessons.excerpt: "Iron sharpens iron; so a man sharpens his friend's countenance." — Proverbs 27:17 (WEB)
lessons.summary: The book of Proverbs is packed with wisdom about friendship. It tells us that good friends make each other better — like two pieces of iron that sharpen each other. It also says that honest words from a friend, even if they sting a little, are worth more than flattery. God wants us to have friendships where we can be truthful, grow together, and become stronger people.
questions: Has a friend ever told you something honest that was hard to hear but helped you grow?
What does it mean to 'sharpen' a friend — how do friends make each other better?
How can you be honest with a friend while still being kind and loving?

missions.title: Encouragement Exchange
missions.desc: Tell a friend one thing you admire about them and one area where you can grow together.

missions.title: Wisdom Duo
missions.desc: Read a chapter of Proverbs with a friend and pick out your favorite verse about friendship. Talk about what it means.

missions.title: Accountability Partners
missions.desc: Ask a trusted friend to be your accountability partner for a goal or habit for two weeks — check in with each other regularly.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to have an honest conversation with a friend about growing together?
Did being accountable to someone help you stick with your goal? Why or why not?
How does God use your friendships to shape you into a better person?

lessons.title: When Friends Mess Up
lessons.excerpt: "Then Peter came and said to him, 'Lord, how often shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? Until seven times?' Jesus said to him, 'I don't tell you until seven times, but, until seventy times seven.'" — Matthew 18:21-22 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Peter thought he was being generous when he asked if he should forgive someone seven times. But Jesus said to forgive seventy times seven — meaning there's no limit! He then told the parable of a servant who was forgiven a huge debt but refused to forgive a small one. Jesus teaches us that since God forgives us so much, we should also forgive our friends when they hurt us.
questions: Is there a time when a friend hurt your feelings? Was it hard to forgive them?
Why do you think the servant in the parable refused to forgive the small debt after being forgiven a huge one?
What can you do when you feel angry or hurt by a friend to start the process of forgiveness?

missions.title: Forgiveness Prayer
missions.desc: Think of someone who hurt your feelings and say a prayer asking God to help you forgive them.

missions.title: Make Things Right
missions.desc: If there's a friend you've had a disagreement with, reach out and talk to them about it — listen to their side and work toward peace.

missions.title: Forgiveness Journal
missions.desc: Keep a journal for one week. Each day, write about a moment where you chose forgiveness or let go of frustration — and how it made you feel.

reflectPrompts: How did it feel to let go of hurt or anger toward someone?
Did forgiving someone change your friendship or how you feel inside?
How does knowing that God always forgives you make it easier to forgive others?

lessons.title: The Greatest Friend of All
lessons.excerpt: "Greater love has no one than this, that someone lay down his life for his friends. You are my friends if you do whatever I command you. No longer do I call you servants, for the servant doesn't know what his lord does. But I have called you friends, for everything that I heard from my Father, I have made known to you." — John 15:13-15 (WEB)
lessons.summary: In His last hours with His disciples, Jesus shared something amazing: He didn't just call them servants or followers — He called them friends. And then He showed the greatest love of all by giving His life for them — and for us. Jesus is the ultimate example of friendship. He loves without limits, forgives endlessly, and invites each of us into a real, personal relationship with Him.
questions: What does it mean to you that Jesus calls you His friend?
How is Jesus' friendship different from other friendships you have?
Looking back at everything we've learned, what's the most important thing about being a good friend?

missions.title: Letter to Jesus
missions.desc: Write a short letter or prayer to Jesus, thanking Him for being your friend and telling Him what His friendship means to you.

missions.title: Friendship Showcase
missions.desc: Create something — a drawing, poem, song, or video — that expresses what you've learned about true friendship and share it with someone.

missions.title: Friendship Legacy
missions.desc: Choose three friendship lessons from this path and put them into practice over the next month. Keep a record of how they change your relationships.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to reflect on Jesus as your closest friend?
How has learning about friendship in the Bible changed the way you treat your friends?
How can you carry what you've learned into every friendship for the rest of your life?

title: Family
desc: Discover what the Bible teaches about loving, honoring, and growing as a family.

lessons.title: Honor Your Father and Mother
lessons.excerpt: "Children, obey your parents in the Lord, for this is right. 'Honor your father and mother,' which is the first commandment with a promise: 'that it may be well with you, and you may live long on the earth.'" — Ephesians 6:1-3 (WEB)
lessons.summary: God gave us a very special commandment about families — to honor our parents! This doesn't just mean obeying rules; it means showing love, respect, and gratitude to the people who care for us. When we honor our parents, we're also honoring God, and He promises that good things will follow.
questions: What does it mean to 'honor' someone? Can you think of a time you showed honor to a parent or caregiver?
Why do you think God made honoring parents one of the Ten Commandments — so important it made the top ten list?
What's one way you could show more honor to your parents or caregivers this week, even when it's hard?

missions.title: Thank-You Note
missions.desc: Write a short note or draw a picture thanking a parent or caregiver for something specific they do for you.

missions.title: Cheerful Helper
missions.desc: Choose three chores or tasks this week and do them without being asked — with a joyful attitude!

missions.title: Honor Week Challenge
missions.desc: For seven days, find a different way each day to honor your parents — kind words, help around the house, obeying quickly, or a surprise act of love.

reflectPrompts: How did it feel to do something kind for your parent or caregiver without being asked?
Did honoring your parents change the way your home felt this week?
How do you think God feels when He sees you showing love and respect to your family?

lessons.title: Brothers and Sisters — Learning to Get Along
lessons.excerpt: "Esau ran to meet him, embraced him, fell on his neck, kissed him, and they wept." — Genesis 33:4 (WEB)
lessons.summary: The Bible tells us about brothers who had big problems — Cain was jealous of Abel, and Jacob tricked Esau out of his blessing. Jealousy and fighting can tear families apart! But the story of Jacob and Esau also shows us that reconciliation is possible. After many years apart, Esau chose to forgive and embrace his brother instead of staying angry.
questions: Have you ever felt jealous of a brother, sister, or friend? What happened?
Why do you think Esau chose to hug Jacob instead of staying angry after so many years?
When you have an argument with a sibling or friend, what's one thing you could do to start making peace?

missions.title: Compliment Coupon
missions.desc: Give a sibling, cousin, or close friend three genuine compliments today — tell them something you admire about them.

missions.title: Their Choice Day
missions.desc: Let a sibling or friend choose the game, show, or activity for the day — and participate with a great attitude, even if it's not your favorite.

missions.title: Peacemaker Project
missions.desc: If you have an ongoing disagreement with a sibling or friend, take the first step to make peace. Apologize for your part, listen to their feelings, and work together on a solution.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to put someone else's preferences ahead of your own?
Did being kind to a sibling or friend change how you felt about them?
How do you think God helps us let go of jealousy and choose love instead?

lessons.title: Joseph and His Brothers — Forgiveness and Restoration
lessons.excerpt: "As for you, you meant evil against me, but God meant it for good, to save many people alive, as it is today." — Genesis 50:20 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Joseph's brothers were so jealous of him that they sold him into slavery! Joseph went through years of hardship — but God was with him the whole time and raised him up to save an entire nation from famine. When his brothers came to him afraid, Joseph chose forgiveness instead of revenge. He saw that God can use even painful family moments for an amazing purpose.
questions: Has someone in your family ever hurt your feelings? How did it make you feel inside?
Joseph said God turned something bad into something good. Can you think of a hard time that eventually led to something better?
Why is forgiving a family member sometimes harder than forgiving a stranger — and why is it so important?

missions.title: Forgiveness Prayer
missions.desc: Think of someone in your family you need to forgive. Say a quiet prayer asking God to help you let go of the hurt.

missions.title: Restoration Letter
missions.desc: Write a letter or have a conversation with a family member you've been upset with. Tell them you forgive them or ask for their forgiveness.

missions.title: Good from Hard Things Journal
missions.desc: For one week, keep a journal where you write about difficult family moments and look for ways God might be working something good through them.

reflectPrompts: How did it feel to pray about forgiving someone or to talk with them about it?
Did choosing forgiveness change anything inside your heart — even a little?
How does knowing that God can bring good from hard times give you hope for your family?

lessons.title: Mary, Joseph, and Jesus — A Faithful Family Under Pressure
lessons.excerpt: "And he went down with them and came to Nazareth. He was subject to them, and his mother kept all these sayings in her heart. And Jesus increased in wisdom and stature, and in favor with God and men." — Luke 2:51-52 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Mary and Joseph faced incredible challenges — an unexpected baby, fleeing to Egypt, and raising the Son of God! Yet they trusted God every step of the way. Even Jesus, as a boy, respected and obeyed His earthly parents. Their story shows us that faithful families stick together through hard times, lean on God, and grow stronger because of it.
questions: Has your family ever gone through a really tough time? How did you get through it together?
Why do you think it matters that even Jesus obeyed and respected Mary and Joseph?
What's one thing your family could do to trust God more when life gets stressful or scary?

missions.title: Family Prayer Moment
missions.desc: Gather your family for a short prayer time. Share one challenge your family is facing and pray about it together.

missions.title: Story Swap Night
missions.desc: Ask a parent or grandparent to share a story about a hard time in your family's past and how God helped them get through it.

missions.title: Family Faith Challenge
missions.desc: Pick a challenge your family is currently facing. Each day for a week, do one thing together to address it with faith — pray, encourage each other, serve one another, or read a Bible verse about trusting God.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to hear your family's stories or pray together about real challenges?
Did going through something hard together make your family feel closer?
How do you see God being faithful to your family, even in tough times?

lessons.title: Teaching and Guiding — The Role of Parents
lessons.excerpt: "These words, which I command you today, shall be on your heart; and you shall teach them diligently to your children, and shall talk of them when you sit in your house, and when you walk by the way, and when you lie down, and when you rise up." — Deuteronomy 6:6-7 (WEB)
lessons.summary: God gave parents an incredible job — to teach their children about His love and His ways! This verse says parents should talk about God's Word all the time: at home, on the road, at bedtime, and in the morning. Learning about God isn't just for church; it's a family adventure that happens every single day, and kids play a big role by listening, asking questions, and growing.
questions: What's something important about God or life that a parent, grandparent, or mentor has taught you?
Why do you think God wants families to talk about Him at all different times of day — not just at church?
How can you be a good learner at home and help your family grow in faith together?

missions.title: Ask and Learn
missions.desc: Ask a parent or caregiver one question about God or the Bible today and listen carefully to their answer.

missions.title: Family Devotion Night
missions.desc: Plan and lead a short family devotion — pick a Bible verse, read it aloud, and ask everyone to share what it means to them.

missions.title: Faith All Day Long
missions.desc: For five days, find a way to bring God into ordinary family moments — pray before a car ride, discuss a Bible story at dinner, or share something you learned about God at bedtime.

reflectPrompts: What did you learn from talking with your family about faith this week?
How did it feel to lead or participate in a family devotion or faith conversation?
In what ways do you think God uses your family to help you grow closer to Him?

lessons.title: Love Is Patient, Love Is Kind — At Home
lessons.excerpt: "Love is patient and is kind. Love doesn't envy. Love doesn't brag, is not proud, doesn't behave itself inappropriately, doesn't seek its own way, is not provoked, takes no account of evil." — 1 Corinthians 13:4-5 (WEB)
lessons.summary: The famous 'love chapter' in the Bible paints a beautiful picture of what real love looks like — and it starts at home! Being patient with a little sibling, being kind when you're tired, and not keeping score of wrongs — that's love in action. God wants our homes to be full of this kind of love, and every family member can practice it every day.
questions: Which part of this description of love is hardest for you — patience, kindness, not keeping score, or something else?
Why do you think it's sometimes easier to be patient and kind with friends than with your own family?
If your family practiced this kind of love for a whole week, what do you think would change?

missions.title: Patience Practice
missions.desc: The next time a family member annoys you or things don't go your way at home, pause, take a deep breath, and respond with patience instead of frustration.

missions.title: Secret Kindness Agent
missions.desc: Do three secret acts of kindness for family members this week — fold their laundry, make their bed, leave a kind note — without telling anyone!

missions.title: Love Checklist Week
missions.desc: Write out the qualities of love from 1 Corinthians 13:4-7 on a checklist. Each day, try to practice every quality at home and check them off. At the end of the week, reflect on which ones you grew in.

reflectPrompts: Which quality of love was easiest to practice at home? Which was the most challenging?
How did your family respond when you showed patience or secret kindness?
How do you think God's love for you helps you love your family better?

lessons.title: Building Your House on the Rock
lessons.excerpt: "Everyone therefore who hears these words of mine and does them, I will liken him to a wise man who built his house on a rock. The rain came down, the floods came, and the winds blew and beat on that house; and it didn't fall, for it was founded on the rock." — Matthew 7:24-25 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus told a story about two builders — one wise and one foolish. The wise builder put his house on solid rock, and it stood strong through every storm. The foolish builder chose sand, and his house fell apart. Our families are like houses! When we build on God's Word — listening to it and actually doing it — our family can stand strong through any challenge life throws our way.
questions: What are some 'storms' that families face — hard things that test how strong a family is?
What does it look like to build your family on 'the rock' of God's Word instead of 'sand'?
What's one thing your family could start doing today to make your foundation stronger?

missions.title: Foundation Stone
missions.desc: Choose one Bible verse as a 'foundation stone' for your family. Write it on a card and put it somewhere everyone can see — the fridge, a mirror, or the front door.

missions.title: Family Blueprint
missions.desc: Sit down with your family and create a short list of values or promises based on the Bible that your family wants to live by — your family's 'blueprint.'

missions.title: 30-Day Family Foundation
missions.desc: Commit as a family to a 30-day challenge: read a short Bible passage together each day, discuss one way to apply it, and check in each week on how you're growing as a family.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to work with your family on building a stronger foundation together?
Do you feel more prepared as a family to face hard times after this experience?
How does knowing that God is your family's rock give you peace and confidence?

title: Old Testament Heroes
desc: Meet the brave men and women of the Old Testament who trusted God against all odds.

lessons.title: Abraham's Big Adventure
lessons.excerpt: "Now Yahweh said to Abram, 'Leave your country, and your relatives, and your father's house, and go to the land that I will show you.'" — Genesis 12:1 (WEB)
lessons.summary: God asked Abraham to leave everything he knew — his home, his family, and his country — and travel to a land he had never seen. Abraham trusted God's promise even though he didn't know where he was going, and God promised to make him into a great nation. His brave obedience reminds us that following God sometimes means stepping into the unknown.
questions: Have you ever had to leave somewhere familiar, like moving to a new school or neighborhood? How did it feel?
Why do you think Abraham was willing to leave everything behind when God asked him to?
What is one area of your life where you could trust God more, even when you can't see the whole plan?

missions.title: Trust Letter
missions.desc: Write a short letter to God about something you're unsure about and tell Him you trust His plan.

missions.title: New Territory
missions.desc: Try something new this week that feels a little scary — a new food, a new activity, or talking to someone you don't usually talk to. Journal about how it went.

missions.title: Adventure of Faith
missions.desc: For one full week, start each morning by praying, 'God, I'll follow wherever You lead today.' At the end of each day, write down one way you saw God guide you.

reflectPrompts: What was the hardest part about stepping into something new or unknown?
How did it feel to trust God with something you couldn't fully see or control?
In what ways did you notice God showing up during your mission?

lessons.title: Moses and the Burning Bush
lessons.excerpt: "Come now therefore, and I will send you to Pharaoh, that you may bring my people, the children of Israel, out of Egypt." — Exodus 3:10 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Moses was just a shepherd when God spoke to him from a burning bush and gave him an enormous job — go to the most powerful king in the world and demand freedom for God's people. Moses was scared and full of excuses, but God promised to be with him every step of the way. This story shows us that God doesn't call the qualified — He qualifies the called.
questions: Have you ever felt like you weren't good enough or brave enough to do something important? What happened?
Moses gave God lots of excuses. Why do you think God was patient with him instead of choosing someone else?
If God asked you to do something big and scary for Him, what would help you say yes?

missions.title: Excuse Burner
missions.desc: Write down one excuse you often make for not doing something good or hard. Pray about it, then crumple up the paper as a symbol of letting that excuse go.

missions.title: Speak Up
missions.desc: Find a situation this week where you can speak up for someone who needs help — a classmate, sibling, or friend. Stand up for what's right, even if it feels uncomfortable.

missions.title: Unlikely Hero
missions.desc: Take on a responsibility that feels bigger than you — volunteer to lead something at school, church, or home. Ask God for courage each day and write about what you learn.

reflectPrompts: What excuse did you have to push past in order to complete your mission?
How did it feel to step up even when you didn't feel fully ready?
How did you sense God's help or presence while doing something brave?

lessons.title: Joshua: Strong and Courageous
lessons.excerpt: "Haven't I commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Don't be afraid. Don't be dismayed, for Yahweh your God is with you wherever you go." — Joshua 1:9 (WEB)
lessons.summary: After Moses died, Joshua was chosen to lead the entire nation of Israel into the Promised Land. It was a huge and terrifying responsibility — there were enemies, walled cities, and an entire people depending on him. But God told Joshua three times to be strong and courageous because He would never leave his side. True courage isn't the absence of fear; it's trusting God in the middle of it.
questions: What is something that makes you feel afraid or nervous? How do you usually handle that fear?
God told Joshua to be strong and courageous multiple times. Why do you think He repeated it?
How can remembering that God is with you change the way you face a tough situation this week?

missions.title: Courage Card
missions.desc: Write Joshua 1:9 on a card or sticky note and put it somewhere you'll see it every day — your mirror, locker, or bedside table.

missions.title: Face the Mountain
missions.desc: Identify one thing you've been avoiding because it scares you. With prayer and a plan, take a real step toward facing it this week.

missions.title: Courage Journal
missions.desc: Keep a daily courage journal for one week. Each day, write about one moment you chose bravery over fear, and how you felt God's presence in that moment.

reflectPrompts: What moment during your mission required the most courage from you?
Did your feelings about fear change at all through this experience? How?
How did remembering God's promise to be with you make a difference?

lessons.title: Gideon: The Unlikely Warrior
lessons.excerpt: "Yahweh is with you, you mighty man of valor." — Judges 6:12 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Gideon was the least important person in his family, from the weakest clan in his tribe — and he was hiding from the enemy when God's angel called him a "mighty man of valor." God saw in Gideon what Gideon couldn't see in himself. Then God shrank Gideon's army from 32,000 to just 300, proving that the victory belonged to God, not to human strength. This story teaches us that God loves to use the small and the overlooked to do amazing things.
questions: Have you ever felt too small, too young, or too unimportant to make a difference? What was that like?
Why do you think God kept making Gideon's army smaller instead of bigger?
How does knowing that God sees you as valuable — no matter what — change how you see yourself?

missions.title: God's Mirror
missions.desc: Look in the mirror and say out loud three good things God made you to be. Write them down and keep the list somewhere special.

missions.title: Small but Mighty
missions.desc: Do one kind act this week for someone who usually gets overlooked — a quiet classmate, a younger kid, or someone who seems lonely. Notice how something small can make a big difference.

missions.title: Underdog Week
missions.desc: Spend a week encouraging people who feel small or left out. Each day, find someone different and tell them something genuinely encouraging. Track how it affects them and you.

reflectPrompts: What did it feel like to encourage someone who might feel overlooked?
Did this mission change how you see your own abilities or worth? How?
How does Gideon's story help you trust that God can use you just as you are?

lessons.title: David vs. Goliath: Facing Giants
lessons.excerpt: "Then David said to the Philistine, 'You come to me with a sword, with a spear, and with a javelin; but I come to you in the name of Yahweh of Armies, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied.'" — 1 Samuel 17:45 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Everyone in Israel's army was terrified of the giant warrior Goliath — everyone except a young shepherd boy named David. While the soldiers saw an unbeatable enemy, David saw someone who had insulted the living God. Armed with just a sling, five stones, and an unshakeable faith, David ran toward the giant and defeated him. David's story reminds us that with God on our side, no problem is too big to face.
