questions: What are the 'giants' in your life — big problems or fears that feel impossible to overcome?
The trained soldiers were afraid, but young David wasn't. What made David different from everyone else?
How can you 'run toward your giant' this week instead of running away from a challenge?

missions.title: Five Smooth Stones
missions.desc: Find or draw five small stones. On each one, write something true about God (e.g., 'God is strong,' 'God is with me'). Keep them as reminders when you face something hard.

missions.title: Giant Slayer
missions.desc: Pick one problem or challenge you've been avoiding. Make a plan to tackle it this week, praying for God's help before each step you take.

missions.title: Run Toward It
missions.desc: For one week, instead of avoiding hard or scary things, face them head-on with prayer. Keep a journal of each 'giant' you faced, what you did, and what happened.

reflectPrompts: What 'giant' did you face this week, and what happened when you stepped forward?
How did praying or trusting God change the way you felt about the challenge?
What did you learn about yourself and about God through this experience?

lessons.title: Elijah: Standing Alone for Truth
lessons.excerpt: "Elijah came near to all the people, and said, 'How long will you waver between the two sides? If Yahweh is God, follow him; but if Baal, then follow him.' The people didn't say a word." — 1 Kings 18:21 (WEB)
lessons.summary: The prophet Elijah stood alone on Mount Carmel against 450 prophets of the false god Baal. While the whole nation had turned away from God, Elijah boldly challenged everyone to choose whom they would serve. God answered Elijah's prayer by sending fire from heaven, proving once and for all that He alone is the true God. Elijah's courage reminds us that standing for truth matters even when you're the only one doing it.
questions: Have you ever been the only one standing up for what's right? How did it feel to be outnumbered?
Why do you think the people 'didn't say a word' when Elijah challenged them to choose?
What's one truth about God you want to stand for, even if others around you don't?

missions.title: Light in the Dark
missions.desc: The next time someone around you says something unkind or untrue, gently speak up with kindness and truth. Afterward, write about what happened.

missions.title: Bold Declaration
missions.desc: Share something you believe about God with a friend, family member, or classmate this week — even if it feels a little awkward. It could be a Bible verse, a prayer, or your own testimony.

missions.title: Mountaintop Stand
missions.desc: For one week, commit to not going along with the crowd when it means doing something wrong. Each evening, write about the moments you chose to stand firm and how God helped you.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to stand for truth when it would have been easier to stay silent?
Did standing up for what's right feel lonely, empowering, or both? Why?
How did you see God support you when you chose to be bold for Him?

lessons.title: Daniel: Faithful in the Lions' Den
lessons.excerpt: "My God has sent his angel, and has shut the lions' mouths, and they have not hurt me, because before him innocence was found in me; and also before you, O king, I have done no harm." — Daniel 6:22 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Daniel was one of the most respected officials in the kingdom, but jealous rivals tricked the king into making a law that banned prayer to anyone except the king himself. Daniel knew the law could get him killed, but he kept praying to God three times a day with his windows wide open. He was thrown into a den of hungry lions, but God sent an angel to shut the lions' mouths. Daniel's story teaches us that faithfulness to God — even when it's dangerous — is always worth it.
questions: If someone told you that you couldn't pray or talk about God anymore, what would you do?
Daniel didn't hide his faith — he prayed with his windows open. Why do you think that detail matters?
What does Daniel's story teach you about staying faithful even when it costs you something?

missions.title: Open Window Prayer
missions.desc: Like Daniel, pray openly at least once today — before a meal, before bed, or before school. Don't hide it, even if others are watching.

missions.title: Three Times a Day
missions.desc: Follow Daniel's example and pray three times every day for a full week — morning, midday, and evening. Keep a simple log of each prayer time.

missions.title: Lions' Den Challenge
missions.desc: Identify a situation where living out your faith feels risky or uncomfortable. Commit to being faithful in that area for a full week, trusting God with the outcome. Journal about each day.

reflectPrompts: What was hardest about being openly faithful during your mission?
How did it feel to keep going even when it was uncomfortable or risky?
In what ways did you experience God's protection or peace, like Daniel did in the lions' den?

title: Women of the Bible
desc: Meet courageous women whose faith shaped history and inspires us today.

lessons.title: Esther: Courage for Such a Time as This
lessons.excerpt: "For if you remain silent now, then relief and deliverance will arise to the Jews from another place, but you and your father's house will perish. Who knows whether you haven't come to the kingdom for such a time as this?" — Esther 4:14 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Esther was a young Jewish woman who became queen of Persia. When an evil man named Haman plotted to destroy all the Jewish people, Esther's cousin Mordecai reminded her that perhaps God had placed her in the palace for this very moment. Even though approaching the king without being invited could cost her life, Esther bravely chose to speak up and save her people.
questions: Have you ever been in a situation where you were the only one who could help someone? What did you do?
Why do you think Esther was afraid to go to the king, and what gave her the courage to do it anyway?
How can you use whatever position or abilities God has given you to stand up for others this week?

missions.title: Speak Up for Someone
missions.desc: Find one opportunity today to speak a kind or encouraging word to someone who is being left out or treated unfairly.

missions.title: Letter of Courage
missions.desc: Write a letter or card to someone going through a hard time, reminding them they are not alone and that you care about them.

missions.title: Be an Esther All Week
missions.desc: For one full week, look for daily opportunities to stand up for others, speak truth, or use your unique position to help people around you. Keep a journal of each moment.

reflectPrompts: What happened when you spoke up or encouraged someone? How did they respond?
Did it feel scary to stand up for someone? What helped you find your courage?
How do you think God might be placing you in special positions to help others, just like He did with Esther?

lessons.title: Ruth: A Heart of Faithfulness
lessons.excerpt: "Ruth said, 'Don't urge me to leave you, and to return from following you, for where you go, I will go; and where you stay, I will stay. Your people will be my people, and your God my God.'" — Ruth 1:16 (WEB)
lessons.summary: After Ruth's husband died, she could have gone back to her own family and her own country. Instead, she chose to stay with her mother-in-law Naomi, leaving behind everything she knew to follow Naomi's God. Ruth's incredible loyalty and trust in God's plan led her on a beautiful journey where she eventually married Boaz and became the great-grandmother of King David — and part of the family line of Jesus!
questions: Who is someone in your life that you are deeply loyal to? What makes that relationship special?
Why do you think Ruth chose to stay with Naomi instead of taking the easier path back home?
How can being faithful to the people God has placed in your life lead to unexpected blessings?

missions.title: Loyal Friend Moment
missions.desc: Do something kind today for a friend or family member to show them you are loyal and care about them — even when it's not convenient.

missions.title: Family Helper
missions.desc: Choose one family member and serve them this week by helping with their chores or responsibilities without being asked, just like Ruth served Naomi.

missions.title: 30-Day Faithfulness Challenge
missions.desc: Pick one relationship and commit to showing faithfulness every day for a month — through notes, acts of service, or quality time. Track your journey in a journal.

reflectPrompts: What did it feel like to show loyalty or kindness to someone even when it cost you something?
Did you notice any unexpected blessings or good things that came from being faithful?
How do you think God's faithfulness to you is reflected in the way you can be faithful to others?

lessons.title: Deborah: Leading with Wisdom and Strength
lessons.excerpt: "Deborah said to Barak, 'Go! For this is the day in which Yahweh has delivered Sisera into your hand. Hasn't Yahweh gone out before you?'" — Judges 4:14 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Deborah was a prophetess and judge of Israel — a leader chosen by God during a very difficult time. When the Israelites were oppressed by a powerful enemy army, Deborah called on a warrior named Barak to lead the fight, but he would only go if she came with him. Deborah boldly agreed and reminded him that it was God who would give them victory. Her wisdom, faith, and courage helped an entire nation find freedom.
questions: What does it look like to be a good leader? Can you name a leader you admire and explain why?
Why do you think Barak wanted Deborah to go with him into battle? What does that say about her character?
In what areas of your life — at school, at home, or with friends — can you lead with wisdom and kindness?

missions.title: Lead One Thing
missions.desc: Take the lead on one task today — like organizing a game, helping a younger sibling with homework, or volunteering to go first — and do it with encouragement for others.

missions.title: Wise Decision Maker
missions.desc: The next time you face a choice this week, pause and pray about it before deciding. Write down what you chose and why, and how seeking God's wisdom helped.

missions.title: Lead a Group Project
missions.desc: Take on a leadership role in a school project, church group, or family activity for an entire week. Focus on encouraging others, listening well, and relying on God's guidance.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to take the lead? Was it easier or harder than you expected?
How did seeking God's wisdom change the way you made decisions or led others?
Do you think God can use kids and teens as leaders just like He used Deborah? Why or why not?

lessons.title: Mary: Saying Yes to God's Amazing Plan
lessons.excerpt: "Mary said, 'See, the handmaid of the Lord; be it to me according to your word.' The angel departed from her." — Luke 1:38 (WEB)
lessons.summary: When the angel Gabriel appeared to a young woman named Mary and told her she would give birth to God's Son, it must have been both amazing and terrifying. Mary didn't fully understand how everything would work out, but she trusted God and said yes. Her humble willingness to follow God's plan — even when it was scary and didn't make sense — changed the entire world forever.
questions: Has God or someone you trust ever asked you to do something that felt really big or scary? How did you respond?
Why do you think Mary was able to say yes even though she didn't understand everything about God's plan?
What is one area of your life where you could practice saying 'yes' to what God is asking of you?

missions.title: Say Yes Today
missions.desc: When a parent, teacher, or friend asks you to do something today, say yes cheerfully — even if it's not what you planned or wanted to do.

missions.title: Trust Journal
missions.desc: Write about something in your life that feels uncertain or hard to understand. Then write a prayer telling God you trust Him with it, just like Mary trusted God's plan.

missions.title: One Month of Yes
missions.desc: For one month, commit to saying yes to God each day. Pray each morning asking God to show you what He wants you to do, then follow through. Journal about your experiences each evening.

reflectPrompts: What happened when you said yes to something that felt uncomfortable or unexpected?
How did it feel to trust God with something you didn't fully understand?
In what ways do you think God is working in your life right now, even if you can't see the full picture yet?

lessons.title: Rahab: Unlikely Faith and Second Chances
lessons.excerpt: "By faith, Rahab the prostitute didn't perish with those who were disobedient, having received the spies in peace." — Hebrews 11:31 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Rahab lived in the city of Jericho and had not lived a perfect life. But when two Israelite spies came to her city, she recognized that their God was the true God and bravely hid them from danger. Because of her faith and courage, Rahab and her whole family were saved when Jericho fell. Even more amazing, Rahab became part of the family line of Jesus! Her story shows us that God offers second chances to everyone.
questions: Have you ever been given a second chance at something? How did it feel to get a fresh start?
What do you think gave Rahab the courage to risk her safety to help the Israelite spies?
How does Rahab's story change the way you think about people who have made mistakes?

missions.title: Give a Second Chance
missions.desc: Think of someone who has upset you or made a mistake. Choose to forgive them today and give them a fresh start in your heart.

missions.title: Encouragement for the Overlooked
missions.desc: Write a kind note or do something special for someone who is often left out or overlooked. Show them they are valued and that God sees them.

missions.title: Second Chances Project
missions.desc: For two weeks, look for people who need a second chance — at school, in your neighborhood, or in your family. Keep a journal of how you showed grace and what happened as a result.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to forgive someone or give them a second chance? Was it easy or hard?
How did it feel to encourage someone who might have been overlooked or forgotten?
How does knowing that God gives everyone second chances — no matter their past — make you feel about His love for you?

lessons.title: Hannah: Praying with Persistence and Trust
lessons.excerpt: "For this child I prayed, and Yahweh has given me my petition which I asked of him." — 1 Samuel 1:27 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Hannah desperately wanted a child, but year after year her prayer went unanswered. Other people even made fun of her. But Hannah never gave up — she kept pouring out her heart to God with honesty and deep trust. When God finally blessed her with a son named Samuel, Hannah kept her promise and dedicated him back to God. Samuel grew up to become one of Israel's greatest prophets. Hannah's story teaches us that God hears every prayer and answers in His perfect timing.
questions: Is there something you have been praying about for a long time? How does it feel to wait for an answer?
Why do you think it was important that Hannah kept praying even when it seemed like nothing was happening?
How can Hannah's example help you when you feel like giving up on something you've been asking God for?

missions.title: Heartfelt Prayer
missions.desc: Spend five quiet minutes today talking to God honestly about something that matters deeply to you — just like Hannah poured out her heart.

missions.title: Prayer Journal Week
missions.desc: Start a prayer journal this week. Each day, write down one thing you are praying for and how you are feeling about it. At the end of the week, look back and see how God has been at work.

missions.title: 30-Day Prayer Commitment
missions.desc: Pick one important prayer request and commit to praying about it every single day for 30 days. Record your thoughts, feelings, and any answers you notice along the way.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to pour out your heart honestly to God? Did anything surprise you about the experience?
How did keeping a prayer journal or praying consistently change the way you think about talking to God?
Do you trust that God hears your prayers even when the answer hasn't come yet? What helps you keep trusting?

lessons.title: The Proverbs 31 Woman: Strength, Dignity, and Character
lessons.excerpt: "Strength and dignity are her clothing. She laughs at the time to come." — Proverbs 31:25 (WEB)
lessons.summary: The last chapter of Proverbs paints a beautiful picture of a woman whose life overflows with strength, kindness, wisdom, and hard work. She cares for her family, helps those in need, speaks with wisdom, and faces the future without fear — all because her confidence comes from trusting God. This isn't about being perfect; it's about building the kind of character that makes a real difference in the world around you.
questions: What character traits do you admire most in the people you look up to? Which ones would you like to grow in yourself?
What do you think it means to be 'clothed with strength and dignity'? How is that different from outward appearance?
What is one way you can build strong, godly character in your everyday life starting today?

missions.title: Character Moment
missions.desc: Choose one character trait today — like kindness, patience, or honesty — and focus on living it out in every situation you face.

missions.title: Serve Someone in Need
missions.desc: This week, find a practical way to help someone in need — donate items, help a neighbor, or volunteer your time. Do it with joy and without expecting anything in return.

missions.title: Character-Building Challenge
missions.desc: Choose three character traits you want to grow in. Spend one week focused on each trait (three weeks total), practicing it daily and journaling about your growth and struggles.

reflectPrompts: Which character trait did you focus on, and what did you learn about yourself in the process?
How did serving others or working on your character change the way you feel about yourself and your future?
How do you think trusting God helps you face the future with confidence and joy, like the Proverbs 31 woman?

title: Wisdom & Decisions
desc: Learn to make wise choices using Biblical principles and God-given discernment.

lessons.title: The Wisest Wish Ever Made
lessons.excerpt: "Give your servant therefore an understanding heart to judge your people, that I may discern between good and evil; for who is able to judge this great people of yours?" — 1 Kings 3:9 (WEB)
lessons.summary: When young King Solomon could have asked God for anything — riches, fame, or power — he asked for wisdom instead. God was so pleased with Solomon's humble request that He gave him not only great wisdom but also the riches and honor he never asked for. This story shows us that wisdom is the most valuable gift we can seek from God.
questions: If God said you could have anything in the whole world, what would you ask for and why?
Why do you think God was so happy that Solomon asked for wisdom instead of treasure or power?
How can asking God for help making good choices change the way your day goes?

missions.title: Wisdom Prayer
missions.desc: Before bed tonight, pray and ask God for wisdom to make good choices tomorrow. Tell a family member about your prayer.

missions.title: Wise Wish List
missions.desc: Write down three things you'd ask God for. Then rank them — which one would help you AND others the most? Share your list with your family.

missions.title: Solomon's Week
missions.desc: For five days straight, start each morning by praying for wisdom before making any decisions. Keep a short journal of how it changed your choices.

reflectPrompts: What happened when you asked God for wisdom? Did anything feel different about your day?
Was it hard to choose wisdom over other things you wanted? How did it feel?
How do you think God helps you when you ask Him for understanding?

lessons.title: Building on the Rock
lessons.excerpt: "Everyone therefore who hears these words of mine and does them, I will liken him to a wise man who built his house on the rock. The rain came down, the floods came, and the winds blew and beat on that house; and it didn't fall, for it was founded on the rock." — Matthew 7:24-25 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus told a story about two builders — one wise and one foolish. The wise builder took time to build his house on solid rock, while the foolish one built on shifting sand. When storms came, only the rock-built house stood strong. Jesus is teaching us that when we listen to His words and actually live by them, our lives have a strong foundation that can weather any storm.
questions: Have you ever taken a shortcut that didn't work out? What happened?
What do you think the 'rock' and the 'sand' represent in our real lives?
What is one thing Jesus teaches that you could start 'building' your life on this week?

missions.title: Foundation Check
missions.desc: Think of one habit you have — is it built on 'rock' (a good choice) or 'sand' (a shaky one)? Tell a family member what you discovered.

missions.title: Build Something Strong
missions.desc: Pick one teaching of Jesus (like being kind, forgiving, or honest) and practice it deliberately for three days. Write down what happened each day.

missions.title: Storm-Proof Plan
missions.desc: Identify a tough situation you sometimes face (peer pressure, anger, worry). Write out a plan using a Bible truth as your foundation. Practice your plan the next time the 'storm' comes.

reflectPrompts: When you practiced building on a strong foundation, what did you notice?
Did it feel different to have a plan based on God's Word? How so?
How do you think God's teachings protect you when hard times come?

lessons.title: Trust God's GPS
lessons.excerpt: "Trust in Yahweh with all your heart, and don't lean on your own understanding. In all your ways acknowledge him, and he will make your paths straight." — Proverbs 3:5-6 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Sometimes we think we know the best way to handle things on our own, but this proverb reminds us that God sees the bigger picture we can't. When we trust Him completely — even when life is confusing — He promises to guide us along the right path. It's like having the best GPS in the universe, one that never loses signal!
questions: Can you think of a time you were really sure about something, but it turned out you were wrong?
What does it mean to 'lean on your own understanding'? Why is that sometimes risky?
How can you 'acknowledge God' in the small everyday choices you make?

missions.title: Pause and Pray
missions.desc: The next time you have to make a choice today (even a small one), pause for 10 seconds and ask God to guide you. Share what happened with your family.

missions.title: Trust Map
missions.desc: Draw a simple map of your week ahead. At each important moment (school, practice, a hard conversation), write a short prayer asking for God's direction. Follow your Trust Map all week.

missions.title: Blind Trust Walk
missions.desc: With a family member, do a trust walk — one person is blindfolded and the other guides them safely through a room. Then journal about what it felt like to trust someone you couldn't see, and how that relates to trusting God.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to pause and ask God for help with your choices?
Was it easy or hard to trust God instead of just doing what you thought was best?
How did you sense God guiding you this week, even in small ways?

lessons.title: The Narrow Gate
lessons.excerpt: "Enter in by the narrow gate; for the gate is wide and the way is broad that leads to destruction, and many are those who enter in by it. How narrow is the gate and the way is restricted that leads to life! Few are those who find it." — Matthew 7:13-14 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus taught that there are two paths we can take in life. The wide, easy road is popular, but it leads to trouble. The narrow path is harder and fewer people choose it, but it leads to real life. Making wise choices sometimes means doing the unpopular thing and choosing what's right over what's easy.
questions: Have you ever felt pressure to do what everyone else was doing, even when you knew it wasn't right?
Why do you think the 'narrow gate' is harder to choose? What makes the wide road so tempting?
What is one area of your life where you can choose the narrow path this week?

missions.title: Spot the Gates
missions.desc: Today, notice one moment where you have to choose between the easy way and the right way. Choose the right way and tell your family about it.

missions.title: Narrow Path Journal
missions.desc: For three days, write down one choice each day where you picked the harder but better option. At the end, read through your journal and see how it felt.

missions.title: Courageous Choice
missions.desc: Identify something you've been avoiding because it's hard or unpopular (like standing up for someone, admitting a mistake, or saying no to something). Do it this week, pray for courage first, and write about what happened.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to choose the narrow path? Was it as hard as you expected?
How did you feel inside after making the braver choice?
Do you think God was with you when you chose the harder right thing? How could you tell?

lessons.title: Tiny Teachers: Lessons from the Ant
lessons.excerpt: "Go to the ant, you sluggard. Consider her ways, and be wise; which having no chief, overseer, or ruler, provides her bread in the summer, and gathers her food in the harvest." — Proverbs 6:6-8 (WEB)
lessons.summary: The Bible tells us to look at the tiny ant and learn an important lesson! Even without anyone bossing them around, ants work hard, plan ahead, and prepare for the future. God wants us to be diligent too — to not be lazy, but to use our time wisely, take responsibility, and prepare for what's coming.
questions: What's something you tend to put off doing, even though you know you should do it?
Why is it impressive that ants work hard without anyone telling them to? How can you be more like that?
How does planning ahead and working hard connect to being wise?

missions.title: Ant Watch
missions.desc: If you can, find some ants outside and watch them for a few minutes. Notice how they work. Then do one chore without being asked!

missions.title: Plan-Ahead Project
missions.desc: Pick something you need to do this week (homework, a chore, a project). Make a step-by-step plan and complete it ahead of time instead of at the last minute. Share your plan with your family.

missions.title: Diligence Challenge
missions.desc: For five days, wake up and complete your most important task first thing — before screen time, before play. Keep a chart tracking your progress and share what you learned about discipline.

reflectPrompts: How did it feel to get something done without being told or reminded?
Did planning ahead make the task easier or harder than you expected?
How do you think God feels when you use your time and energy wisely?

lessons.title: Better Together: The Gift of Good Advice
lessons.excerpt: "Where there is no counsel, plans fail; but in a multitude of counselors they are established." — Proverbs 15:22 (WEB)
lessons.summary: The Bible teaches us that we aren't meant to figure everything out alone. When we seek advice from wise and godly people — parents, teachers, mentors, and friends who love God — our plans become stronger and our decisions become better. Wise people know that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness.
questions: Who are the people in your life that give you the best advice? What makes their advice good?
Why do you think it's sometimes hard to ask for help or advice?
How can you tell the difference between good advice and bad advice?

missions.title: Ask a Wise One
missions.desc: Think of a decision you need to make (big or small). Ask a parent, grandparent, or trusted adult for their advice before you decide.

missions.title: Wisdom Council
missions.desc: Gather two or three trusted people (family or friends) and share a challenge you're facing. Listen to all their ideas before choosing what to do. Write down what each person suggested.

missions.title: Advice Givers Log
missions.desc: For one week, whenever someone gives you advice, write it down in a journal along with who said it. At the end of the week, review the advice — which pieces were wisest? Thank those people for their guidance.

reflectPrompts: What happened when you asked someone for advice? Was their perspective different from yours?
How did it feel to listen to others before making your decision?
Do you think God places wise people in our lives on purpose? Who has He placed in yours?

lessons.title: Where Wisdom Begins
lessons.excerpt: "The fear of Yahweh is the beginning of wisdom. The knowledge of the Holy One is understanding." — Proverbs 9:10 (WEB)
lessons.summary: This powerful proverb tells us where all true wisdom starts — with respect, awe, and reverence for God. 'The fear of the Lord' doesn't mean being scared of God; it means recognizing how awesome, powerful, and loving He is. When we start with God — honoring Him and wanting to please Him — we unlock the very beginning of all wisdom and understanding.
questions: What do you think 'the fear of the Lord' means? Is it about being scared, or something deeper?
How does knowing God — who He is and what He's like — help you make better choices?
Looking back at this whole path, what's the most important thing you've learned about wisdom?

missions.title: Awe Moment
missions.desc: Spend five minutes outside looking at something God created — the sky, trees, stars. Let yourself feel amazed at how awesome God is. Tell your family about what you noticed.

missions.title: Wisdom Collection
missions.desc: Pick three proverbs from the Book of Proverbs that mean the most to you. Write them out beautifully on paper or a card. Post them somewhere you'll see them every day.

missions.title: Wisdom Graduation
missions.desc: Write a personal 'Wisdom Statement' — a paragraph about what wisdom means to you, how you want to make decisions, and how God fits into your choices. Share it with your family and discuss it together as a celebration of completing this path.

reflectPrompts: When you spent time appreciating God's greatness, how did it make you feel inside?
Has your understanding of wisdom changed since you started this path? How?
How will you keep putting God first in your decisions from here on out?

title: Forgiveness & Grace
desc: Discover the freedom that comes from giving and receiving forgiveness.

lessons.title: As Far as East from West
lessons.excerpt: "As far as the east is from the west, so far has he removed our transgressions from us." — Psalm 103:12 (WEB)
lessons.summary: King David wrote a beautiful song about how completely God forgives us. He said God takes our mistakes and moves them so far away it's like the distance between east and west — they can never come back! This psalm reminds us that God's love is so big and so deep that when He forgives, He truly lets go of our wrongs.
questions: Have you ever done something wrong and felt really bad about it? What happened when you said sorry?
Why do you think David compared forgiveness to the distance between east and west instead of something smaller?
How does knowing God completely removes your mistakes change the way you feel about asking Him for forgiveness?

missions.title: East-West Reminder
missions.desc: Watch a sunrise or sunset today and thank God that His forgiveness stretches even farther than the sky you see.

missions.title: Clean Slate Letter
missions.desc: Write down something you feel guilty about on a piece of paper, then tear it up as a reminder that God removes your wrongs completely.

missions.title: Psalm of Thanks
missions.desc: Write your own short psalm (poem or song) thanking God for His forgiveness. Share it with your family during devotion time.

reflectPrompts: What did it feel like to let go of something you've been carrying guilt about?
Did this experience change how you think about God's forgiveness?
How do you think God feels when you come to Him and ask for a fresh start?

lessons.title: The Servant Who Wouldn't Forgive
lessons.excerpt: "Then Peter came and said to him, 'Lord, how often shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? Until seven times?' Jesus said to him, 'I don't tell you until seven times, but, until seventy times seven.'" — Matthew 18:21-22 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Peter asked Jesus how many times he should forgive someone, thinking seven times was generous. But Jesus said seventy times seven — meaning there's no limit! Then Jesus told a story about a servant who was forgiven a huge debt by his king but then refused to forgive a tiny debt someone owed him. The king was upset because the servant didn't share the same mercy he had received.
questions: Has someone ever kept doing something that annoyed or hurt you? How did it feel to keep forgiving them?
Why do you think the servant in the story forgot how much he had been forgiven?
How can remembering that God forgives you help you forgive someone at school or at home?

missions.title: Seventy Times Seven
missions.desc: Calculate 70 × 7 and write the number somewhere you'll see it today as a reminder that forgiveness has no limit.

missions.title: Forgiveness in Action
missions.desc: Think of someone you're holding a grudge against. Pray for them and do one kind thing for them this week.

missions.title: Forgiveness Journal
missions.desc: Keep a journal for one week. Each day, write about a time you forgave someone or needed forgiveness, and how it made you feel.

reflectPrompts: Was it hard or easy to be kind to someone you needed to forgive? Why?
How did it feel after you chose to forgive instead of holding on to frustration?
Do you think God helped you forgive? How?

lessons.title: Joseph Forgives His Brothers
lessons.excerpt: "As for you, you meant evil against me, but God meant it for good, to save many people alive, as it is today." — Genesis 50:20 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Joseph's brothers were so jealous of him that they sold him into slavery. Joseph spent years suffering — in slavery, in prison — but God was with him the whole time and eventually made him a powerful leader in Egypt. When a famine brought his brothers to him for help, Joseph didn't take revenge. Instead, he forgave them and saw how God had turned their evil into something amazing.
questions: Has someone ever been really unfair to you? How did that make you feel inside?
How do you think Joseph was able to forgive his brothers after everything they did to him?
Can you think of a hard situation in your life that God might be using for something good?

missions.title: Good from Bad
missions.desc: Think of one hard thing that happened to you and write down one good thing that came from it. Thank God for working in that situation.

missions.title: Bridge Builder
missions.desc: Reach out to someone you've had a disagreement with — a sibling, friend, or classmate. Say something kind or offer to make things right.

missions.title: Long-Game Trust
missions.desc: Pick a difficult situation you're going through right now. Each day for a week, pray and write down one way you see God working in it, even if it's small.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to look for good in a hard situation?
Did reaching out to someone or reflecting on hard times change how you feel about what happened?
How does Joseph's story help you trust that God has a plan even when things seem unfair?

lessons.title: Jesus Restores Peter
lessons.excerpt: "So when they had eaten their breakfast, Jesus said to Simon Peter, 'Simon, son of Jonah, do you love me more than these?' He said to him, 'Yes, Lord; you know that I have affection for you.' He said to him, 'Feed my lambs.'" — John 21:15 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Peter had denied even knowing Jesus three times on the night Jesus was arrested. After the resurrection, Jesus found Peter and gently asked him three times, 'Do you love me?' — once for each denial. Instead of scolding Peter, Jesus gave him an important job: to care for His people. Jesus showed that failure doesn't have to be the end — grace gives us a new beginning.
questions: Have you ever let a friend down and felt terrible about it? What happened next?
Why do you think Jesus asked Peter the same question three times?
How does it make you feel to know that Jesus didn't give up on Peter — and won't give up on you?

missions.title: Breakfast of Grace
missions.desc: Share a meal or snack with someone and use it as a chance to talk about fresh starts and second chances.

missions.title: Three Kind Words
missions.desc: Think of someone who has made a mistake recently. Tell them three encouraging things to help lift them up — one for each time Jesus restored Peter.

missions.title: Restoration Project
missions.desc: Is there a relationship in your life that needs healing? Take real steps this week to restore it — apologize, listen, and show love through your actions.

reflectPrompts: What did it feel like to encourage someone who had failed or was feeling down?
Have you experienced a 'fresh start' moment? How did grace play a part in it?
How does knowing Jesus restores people change the way you see your own mistakes?

lessons.title: Grace Meets the Woman at the Well
lessons.excerpt: "Jesus answered her, 'Everyone who drinks of this water will thirst again, but whoever drinks of the water that I will give him will never thirst again; but the water that I will give him will become in him a well of water springing up to eternal life.'" — John 4:13-14 (WEB)
lessons.summary: A Samaritan woman came to draw water at a well in the middle of the day, probably to avoid the judgmental stares of others. Jesus surprised her by starting a conversation — something no one expected, since Jews didn't normally talk to Samaritans. He knew all about her past mistakes but didn't shame her. Instead, He offered her living water — a life overflowing with God's grace and love.
questions: Have you ever felt left out or judged by others? How did that make you feel?
Why do you think Jesus chose to talk to someone everyone else avoided?
What do you think 'living water' means for your everyday life?

missions.title: Living Water
missions.desc: Every time you drink water today, pause and thank God for the grace He pours into your life.

missions.title: The Unexpected Hello
missions.desc: This week, start a friendly conversation with someone who is often left out or overlooked — at school, church, or in your neighborhood.

missions.title: Overflow of Grace
missions.desc: Identify someone in your life who might be carrying shame. Find ways to show them kindness and acceptance every day for a week without expecting anything in return.

reflectPrompts: How did it feel to reach out to someone who is usually left out?
Did showing grace to someone else change how you feel about the grace God shows you?
How do you think God sees people that others judge or avoid?

lessons.title: Zacchaeus — A Life Transformed by Grace
lessons.excerpt: "Jesus said to him, 'Today, salvation has come to this house, because he also is a son of Abraham. For the Son of Man came to seek and to save that which was lost.'" — Luke 19:9-10 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Zacchaeus was a tax collector that everyone disliked because he cheated people out of their money. He was so curious about Jesus that he climbed a tree just to see Him. When Jesus looked up and said He was coming to Zacchaeus's house, everything changed. Grace didn't just forgive Zacchaeus — it transformed him. He gave back everything he had stolen and then some!
questions: Have you ever been so excited about something that you did something silly or brave to see it? What was it?
Why do you think meeting Jesus changed Zacchaeus so quickly and completely?
How can experiencing God's grace change the way we treat other people and handle our mistakes?

missions.title: Tree-Top Faith
missions.desc: Go outside and find a tree. Stand or sit near it and think about what it would be like to want to see Jesus so badly that you'd climb a tree!

missions.title: Give It Back
missions.desc: Think of something you've taken that wasn't yours — someone's time, a borrowed item, or even credit for something. Make it right this week.

missions.title: Generosity Challenge
missions.desc: Like Zacchaeus who gave back four times what he took, go above and beyond in generosity this week. Give away toys, time, or help — more than what's expected of you.

reflectPrompts: How did it feel to make something right or to be extra generous?
Did being generous or making amends change how you see yourself?
How do you think God's grace can turn anyone's life around, no matter what they've done?

lessons.title: Father, Forgive Them
lessons.excerpt: "Jesus said, 'Father, forgive them, for they don't know what they are doing.'" — Luke 23:34 (WEB)
lessons.summary: In His most painful moment on the cross, Jesus didn't cry out for revenge or justice — He asked God to forgive the very people who were hurting Him. This is the ultimate example of forgiveness and grace. If Jesus could forgive from the cross, He shows us that no situation is too hard, and no hurt is too deep, for forgiveness to reach.
questions: What is the hardest thing you've ever had to forgive someone for?
Why do you think Jesus chose to forgive the people who were hurting Him instead of being angry?
How can Jesus' example on the cross help you when you're struggling to forgive someone?

missions.title: Cross Reflection
missions.desc: Find a quiet place, close your eyes, and imagine being at the cross. Think about what it means that Jesus forgave even then. Write or draw what you feel.

missions.title: Release and Forgive
missions.desc: Write the name of someone you need to forgive on a piece of paper. Pray for them, then safely let the paper go (tear it up, release it in the wind) as a symbol of letting go.

missions.title: Radical Forgiveness
missions.desc: Choose to forgive someone who hurt you deeply — even if they haven't apologized. Pray for them daily for one week and look for ways to show them grace.

reflectPrompts: What did it feel like to release someone through forgiveness, even if it was hard?
Has forgiving someone changed something inside of you? What feels different?
How does Jesus' prayer from the cross shape the way you understand God's love and grace?

title: Serving Others
desc: Follow Jesus' example of humble service and discover the joy of putting others first.

lessons.title: The King Who Knelt Down
lessons.excerpt: "If I then, the Lord and the Teacher, have washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another's feet. For I have given you an example, that you also should do as I have done to you." — John 13:14-15 (WEB)
lessons.summary: On the night before He died, Jesus did something that shocked His disciples — He got down on His knees and washed their dirty feet, a job usually given to the lowest servant. By doing this, Jesus showed that true greatness isn't about being served but about serving others with a humble heart.
questions: How would you feel if the most important person you know offered to do something really humble for you, like cleaning your shoes?
Why do you think Jesus chose to wash feet instead of just telling the disciples to serve each other?
What is one small act of service you could do today that no one would expect from you?

missions.title: Secret Servant
missions.desc: Do one chore at home that isn't yours without being asked — and don't tell anyone you did it.

missions.title: Feet First
missions.desc: Offer to help a family member with something they usually do themselves, like setting the table, folding laundry, or organizing their space.

missions.title: A Week of Kneeling
missions.desc: Pick one act of humble service to do every day for a full week — things like helping carry groceries, cleaning up after others, or tidying shared spaces.

reflectPrompts: What was it like to serve someone without being asked or getting credit?
Did serving quietly change how you felt inside? How?
How do you think Jesus feels when He sees you serving others with a humble heart?

lessons.title: The Gift That Outshined Them All
lessons.excerpt: "Most certainly I tell you, this poor widow gave more than all those who are giving into the treasury, for they all gave out of their abundance, but she, out of her poverty, gave all that she had to live on." — Mark 12:43-44 (WEB)
lessons.summary: While rich people dropped big, clanging coins into the offering box at the temple, a poor widow quietly placed two tiny coins — all the money she had. Jesus noticed her and told His disciples that she had given more than everyone else, because she gave everything she had out of love and trust in God.
questions: Have you ever given something away that was really special or hard to part with? How did it feel?
Why did Jesus say the widow gave more than the rich people, even though her coins were worth less?
What is something you could share with someone this week, even if it feels like it's not very much?

missions.title: Small but Mighty Gift
missions.desc: Find something you own that you could give to someone who would enjoy it — a toy, a book, or a drawing you made.

missions.title: Give Your Time
missions.desc: Spend at least 30 minutes of your free time helping someone — a sibling with homework, a neighbor with yard work, or a parent with a project.

missions.title: Save and Share
missions.desc: Set aside a portion of your allowance or money for two weeks and donate it to a cause your family chooses together.

reflectPrompts: What did you give or share, and what made you choose that?
Was it hard to let go of something? What helped you do it anyway?
How do you think God views your offering, no matter how big or small it is?

lessons.title: A Boy's Lunch Feeds Thousands
lessons.excerpt: "There is a boy here who has five barley loaves and two fish, but what are these among so many?" Jesus took the loaves, and having given thanks, he distributed to the disciples, and the disciples to those who were sitting down, likewise also of the fish as much as they desired. — John 6:9-11 (WEB)
lessons.summary: A huge crowd had followed Jesus and everyone was getting hungry. One young boy offered his small lunch of five loaves and two fish. It didn't look like much, but Jesus took it, blessed it, and fed over 5,000 people with plenty of leftovers! God can take whatever we offer — no matter how small — and do amazing things with it.
questions: If you had the only lunch in a crowd of thousands, would you be willing to share it? Why or why not?
What does this story teach us about what God can do with something small?
What is one thing you have — a skill, a talent, or even just your time — that you could offer to help others?

missions.title: Share a Snack
missions.desc: Pack an extra snack or treat and share it with a friend, classmate, or sibling today.

missions.title: Cook and Share
missions.desc: Help your family prepare a meal or baked goods and deliver a portion to a neighbor, friend, or someone who could use encouragement.

missions.title: Organize a Collection
missions.desc: Organize a small food drive — collect canned goods or non-perishable items from family and friends and donate them to a local food bank.

reflectPrompts: What did you share, and how did the other person react?
Did offering something small end up feeling bigger than you expected? How so?
How does it feel to know that God can multiply your small offering into something amazing?

lessons.title: When You Serve Them, You Serve Me
lessons.excerpt: "The King will answer them, 'Most certainly I tell you, because you did it to one of the least of these my brothers, you did it to me.'" — Matthew 25:40 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Jesus told a powerful story about the day when God will separate people like a shepherd separates sheep from goats. Those who fed the hungry, welcomed strangers, clothed the poor, and visited the sick were blessed — because Jesus said that when we help people in need, it's the same as helping Him. Every act of kindness matters to God.
questions: Who are 'the least of these' in your school, neighborhood, or community?
How does it change the way you think about helping others when you imagine you're helping Jesus Himself?
What is one way your family could reach out to someone who is lonely, hungry, or going through a hard time?

missions.title: Kindness Card
missions.desc: Make a handwritten card or letter for someone who might be feeling lonely — a grandparent, a new kid at school, or a neighbor who lives alone.

missions.title: Clothing Care Package
missions.desc: Go through your closet and gather gently used clothes, shoes, or coats to donate to a shelter or clothing drive.

missions.title: Serve the Overlooked
missions.desc: With a parent's help, volunteer at a local soup kitchen, shelter, or community service event. Spend time talking to the people you meet there.

reflectPrompts: Who did you serve, and what was it like to meet or help them?
Did anything surprise you about the experience or how it made you feel?
How did this experience help you see Jesus in the people around you?

lessons.title: Dorcas and Her Giving Hands
lessons.excerpt: "Now there was at Joppa a certain disciple named Tabitha, which when translated, means Dorcas. This woman was full of good works and acts of mercy which she did." — Acts 9:36 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Dorcas was a woman in the early church who used her talent for sewing to make clothes for widows and people in need. When she died, her community was heartbroken — they showed Peter all the robes and garments she had lovingly made. God raised her back to life! Dorcas reminds us that using our everyday talents to serve others can have a powerful, lasting impact.
questions: What are you good at? Drawing, cooking, building, writing, sports — how could you use that talent to help someone?
Why do you think the people were so sad when Dorcas died? What does that tell us about the power of quiet, steady service?
How can using your unique gifts be a way of worshiping God?

missions.title: Talent Share
missions.desc: Use one of your talents to create something for someone else — draw a picture, write a poem, build something, or bake a treat.

missions.title: Teach What You Know
missions.desc: Offer to teach a younger kid or a friend something you're good at — a skill, a game, a craft, or a school subject.

missions.title: Talent Service Project
missions.desc: Plan and carry out a service project using your talents — make blankets for a shelter, create art for a nursing home, or organize a free tutoring session for classmates.

reflectPrompts: What talent did you use, and who did you serve with it?
How did it feel to use something you enjoy doing to bless someone else?
Do you think God gave you your talents for a reason? What might that reason be?

lessons.title: Barnabas: The Friend Everyone Needs
lessons.excerpt: "Joses, who by the apostles was also named Barnabas (which is, being interpreted, Son of Encouragement), a Levite, a man of Cyprus by race, having a field, sold it and brought the money and laid it at the apostles' feet." — Acts 4:36-37 (WEB)
lessons.summary: Barnabas was so generous and uplifting that the apostles gave him a special nickname: 'Son of Encouragement.' He sold his own land to help the early church, and later he was the one who believed in Paul when everyone else was afraid of him. Barnabas shows us that encouraging others and lifting people up is one of the most powerful ways to serve.
questions: Has someone ever encouraged you when you were feeling down or unsure? How did it change things for you?
Why do you think encouragement is such a powerful form of service?
Who in your life could really use some encouragement right now, and how could you give it to them?

missions.title: Encouragement Note
missions.desc: Write a kind note, text, or letter to someone telling them something specific you appreciate about them.

missions.title: Be a Barnabas
missions.desc: Find someone at school or in your community who seems left out or discouraged. Make an effort to include them, sit with them, or stand up for them this week.

missions.title: Encouragement Campaign
missions.desc: Start a week-long encouragement project — write a different person a note of encouragement each day for seven days. Include friends, family, teachers, and someone unexpected.

reflectPrompts: Who did you encourage, and how did they respond?
How did encouraging someone else affect your own mood and outlook?
How do you think God uses encouragement to build His kingdom and strengthen people?

lessons.title: The Greatest Love of All
lessons.excerpt: "This is my commandment, that you love one another, even as I have loved you. Greater love has no one than this, that someone lay down his life for his friends." — John 15:12-13 (WEB)
lessons.summary: In His final teaching to His closest friends, Jesus gave them the ultimate command: love one another the way He loved them. And the greatest kind of love? Giving up what matters most for someone else. Jesus lived this out completely by dying on the cross for us. Sacrificial love — putting others before ourselves — is the heart of what it means to serve like Jesus.
questions: What does it mean to 'lay down your life' for someone? Does it always mean dying, or can it mean other things too?
Can you think of a time when someone gave up something important so you could have what you needed?
What is one thing you could sacrifice — your time, your comfort, your preference — to show love to someone this week?

missions.title: Put Someone First
missions.desc: Let someone else go first today — pick what to watch, choose the game, or have the last treat. Do it cheerfully!

missions.title: Give Up to Lift Up
missions.desc: Give up something you enjoy for a day (screen time, a favorite activity) and spend that time doing something kind for someone else instead.

missions.title: Sacrificial Service Week
missions.desc: Commit to one week of daily sacrificial service — each day, intentionally give up something (time, comfort, preferences) to serve a different person in your life.

reflectPrompts: What did you sacrifice, and who did you serve by doing it?
Was it hard to put someone else first? What helped you follow through?
How does knowing that Jesus made the ultimate sacrifice for you inspire you to serve others?
